column2: OF the trilogy of studies of criminal careers and personalities which Mr. and Mrs. Glueck have written, including, besides this book, examinations of the lives of 500 delinquent men and as many women, this one is perhaps the most important.
A fundamental principle of the Neediest Cases Fund is that all of the money contributed shall go toward the permanent rehabilitation of the unfortunate and not be dissipated on trivialities.

Another concert in the series for the benefit of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association will be held at the Plaza on the night of Jan. 13, when the artist will be Mme. Florence Easton, soprano. A supper will be given at the hotel before the concert.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Public Works Administration loans to railroads for the year ending today amounted to $193,276,500, and provided for about 150,000,000 man-hours of employment, Secretary Ickes said today in a review of such activities. Loans were made to thirty railroad companies.

While the outlook for the capital goods industries during 1935 is definitely brighter, the poor prospects for private building, particularly residential construction, will hold down the percentage increase over the 1934 volume, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by executives in the heavy goods fields.

MONTREAL, Dec. 29. -- Three third period goals gave the New York Americans a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight, enabled them to end a losing streak that had stretched to four games and sent them ahead of their rivals to third position in the International group of the National Hockey League.
The police curfew, which ordinarily requires a 3 A.M. closing of cabarets and night clubs, was lifted yesterday for the benefit of New Year's Eve revelers by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP). -- The NRA today moved further away from price-fixing by ordering the minimum-price provisions of the Waste Paper Code dropped Jan. 7.

IN Europe, where the question of aerial defense has become a matter for urgent preparations, one of the principal issues is what can be done to protect the civilian populations. Even after all the experiments and investigations that have been conducted, French exports in many cases are still giving voice to alarming opinions.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 27. -- In addition to projects for the establishment of metropolitan Pittsburgh upon lines co-extensive with Allegheny County and for consolidation of the city and county of Philadelphia, there is now a general movement on in Pennsylvania against the so-called "ox cart" government principles that have multiplied political subdivisions and taxing bodies.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29.--Leonid Nikolaieff and thirteen other former members of the Communist party who were arrested in Leningrad in connection with the assassination Dec. 1 of Sergei Kiroff, Communist Political Bureau member, have been found guilty and executed by shooting.

IT was in the earliest of Mendelssohn's numerous visits to England (where for many years he was esteemed as the greatest musical composer of his time) that he began his lifelong friendship with the Horsleys, a family of distinction in English culture through-out two generations at least.

CAMDEN, S.C. -- A full season of hunting in the colony is indicated in the recent announcement of the Camden Hunt Hounds of its plans for the next three weeks' hunts, sent to members by Mrs. Dwight Partridge of Bedford Hills, N.Y., M.F.H.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued to strengthen yesterday, and advances of 1 to 4 points established the highest quotations since September, or prior to the decline attending the usual autumnal marketing movement.

THOSE who are interested in the celebration of anniversaries will find the coming year rich in such reminders of famous events or personages. While 1934 marked the twentieth anniversary of the start of the World War and the centenaries of numerous illustrious individuals, the coming year is no less well stocked with dates which will bear observance.

WITH the enormous reservoir of available material on which to draw, it frequently falls to our lot to deplore the sudden issue of new and by no means extraordinary versions of already sevenfold recorded symphonies or overtures.

Fair consumer response to clearances of Winter apparel and accessories featured retail trade in the metropolitan area last week. While several leading establishments are credited with larger increases, revised estimates now place the December gain over a year ago for stores here at 5 to 6 per cent, inclusive of liquor sales.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- General Jan C. Smuts, South African Minister of Justice, who has often acted as an unofficial peacemaker within the British Empire, has written a letter to the Mahatma Gandhi urging him to bring about peace between the British Government and the Indian Nationalist Congress.

GEORGE RUSSELL, that collection of rich and varied personalities, is again a welcome guest among us and playing as genially as ever with ideas. The irony of one of them will hardly be appreciated by our 10,000,000 or so unemployed. Americans work too much, he says.

THE year 1934 was momentous for the American menu and the housewife who planned it. New diet fads, new reducing menus, came and went. But the major place in the news was held by the square meal; women learned about food values and distribution and price as never before.

Three of the four world's professional billiard titles changed hands during the past year, while the fourth was not placed in competition. Welker Cochran of San Francisco, however, emerged from this downfall of champions with one crown still in his possession.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 29. -- The Czechoslovak Minister to Hungary, Milos Kobr, declared today in the newspaper Az Est regarding his recent article in which he discussed a rapprochement between Hungary and Czechoslovakia that such a rapprochement was possible if both countries showed good-will.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 29. -- The committee for the selection of the alumni association nominee for alumni trustee of Rutgers University was announced today by H. Richard Segoine, president of the Rutgers alumni council. Members are elected to the committee by each of the most recent five-year reunion classes.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 29. -- A new and more accurate device for recording the percentage of sunshine, which was expected to advance the measurement and study of vital rays emanating from the sun, has been perfected by Professor L.F. Miller, University of Minnesota physicist.

Every public and parochial school in Queens and the Bronx is taking part in the diphtheria campaign of the Health Department, according to an announcement yesterday from Health Commissioner Rice's office. Health banners will be awarded to the two public and parochial schools having the greatest number of immunization request coupons for children.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during November, given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with a month ago and the corresponding period of 1933. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports.

The well-rounded Johns Hopkins lacrosse team, the dominant figure in the sport for the preceding two seasons, once more attained top honors in 1934, capturing the national intercollegiate championship for the third successive time.

Rene Pugnet was the first man in a long succession of distingushed Pugnets to deviate from their traditional careers in diplomacy, art and science, and turn to the whipping sail, the throbbing engine and the kind of exhilaration that only salt water and its immeasurable spaces can give.
The tremendous growth in squash racquets in this country was reflected in the international competitions that took place during the season of 1933-34.

AN ancient stock situation is revived in this short novel with an effectiveness which bids strongly for the reader's indulgence. During the twenty years of her marriage to John. Marian had been a devoted wife, though she had never divulged to him the fact that Mary Frances, their only child, was really begotten by his brother Clarke shortly before Marian's union with John.

FIFTY MILES up the Hudson River from the great metropolis there are islands where one can still live the life of the Indians, almost completely isolated from civilization. Canoeists moving up the river a few miles above the great Bear Mountain Bridge come to one of these rocky havens from the world and there pitch their tents.

Efforts to study diabetes as a health problem and to devise measures for its control will be undertaken by a new organization -- the New York Diabetes Association -- it was announced yesterday by Dr. I. Ogden Woodruff, president of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, with which it will be associated at 386 Fourth Avenue.
James (Rip) Collins, first baseman of the champion Cardinals, was the outstanding slugger in the National League for the 1934 season, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

WILMINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The Weirton Steel Company filed a 359-page brief in Federal Court here today in answer to charges of the government that the employe-representation plan violated the collective bargaining provisions of Section 7a of the Recovery Act.

Mounting costs of practically all types of food, groceries and meats face consumers in the early months of 1935, authorities in the food industry agreed yesterday. Advances ranging from 5 to 10 per cent are in prospect, with increases running as high as 20 per cent above Fall levels on a few commodities which are held in particularly short supply.

May a country visitor to New York have a word to express his appreciation of the play "The First Legion"? We who come from the hinterland are supposed to make a beeline for bawdy shows. We are presumed to crowd around the box office of smart-cracking Broadway banalities.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29. -- Here follows the text of Dr. Robert A. Millikan's Articles of Faith for a new cosmic ray credo, as explained by him today before the American Association for the Advancement of Science:

PROLIFIC of Western thrillers, William Colt MacDonald has now published four tales dealing with the exploits of his "Three Mesquiteers." the tall, rangy Tucson Smith who is quite as quick with his wits as with his guns, and his companions.

Nearly 85 per cent of the members of the 1934 graduating class at Columbia University have obtained positions, according to W. Emerson Gentzler, secretary of appointments. In his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, made public yesterday, Mr. Gentzler says that men with scientific training are more in demand than any other type of college graduate.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP). -- Lively drills and scrimmage today completed rough work for Bucknell and the University of Miami football squads, which meet here New Year's Day in the Orange Bowl game.

La Argentina in her third recital of the season at the Town Hall last night restored to the program five dances which have not been previously in her present series. All of them belong in the first ranks of her repertoire, and helped to make up what, from a purely programatic standpoint, was the best of her performances thus far.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Knocking out King Levinsky knocked Max Baer, world's heavyweight champion, out of at least $50,000.

PARIS, Dec. 27. -- Old Spanish mantillas are being used to make stunning lace scarfs and jabots; they are also an inspiration for lace evening capelets. All of this is in keeping with the latest style trends.

MEXICO, D.F., Dec. 29. -- Reuben Fine of New York, Arthur W. Dake of Portland and Herman Steiner of Los Angeles, the three representatives of the United States in the international chess masters' tournament in progress here, today won their games in the second round.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- The New Year's resolution of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union is "continued championship of national prohibition of the traffic in beverage alcohol and in other narcotic drugs."

LAKE PLACID, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Miss Margaret Burnford, a 23-year-old English girl, tells of her perilous ski climb up the icy slopes of Mount Marcy, highest peak of the Adirondacks, with three men Thursday buffeted by a fifty-mile wind and braving a temperature of 20 below zero.

LONDON, Dec. 14. YEARS ago, when I was a young naval officer in the China fleet, I went to a Chinese theatre. Having now seen "Lady Precious Stream" performed in London, I wish that my recollection of that far-off evening were less vague, for "Lady Precious Stream" has been adapted by S.I. Hsiung from a traditional Chinese play, and the piece I saw in China sprang also from very ancient sources.

Prices were generally higher in the bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. In the two-hour trading period dealings amounted to $6,712,600, compared with $5,824,200 on the Saturday before. All classifications participated in the rise. United States Government issues, on a turnover of $998,600, closed 8-32 point higher to 2-32 point lower.
Bonthron, Cunningham and Lovelock is the alphabetical order. But the season of 1934 was able to furnish little information as to the ranking of these three magnificent milers on comparative ability.

WINNIPEG, Dec. 29 (Canadian Press). -- The door was open tonight for a flood of damaged Canadian grain to pour into the United States for feeding livestock, suffering from drought-caused feed shortage.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 27. -- The annual report of Governor Blanton Winship reflects both optimism and pessimism in Puerto Rican affairs for the year ended with last June. Contrasting with an improved financial condition in the insular government, due to administrative economies and additional revenues, the Governor points out that the economic situation throughout the island is the most discouraging in recent years.

THIS is the season when the film reviewer fortifies every one's suspicions regarding his probable escape from a home for backward boys by participating in the barbaric custom of naming the ten best photoplays of the past twelvemonth.

Taking cognizance of the "continued agitation for some sort of public ownership or strict regulation of utilities," the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York said in its weekly bulletin released yesterday that "the opinion seems to be that utilities are closer to being legislated out of business than ever before."
In your review of "Benjamin Rush" you make the assertion that Rush was the only physician to sign the Declaration of Independence.

ATTRACTIVE weaves and fine degrees of coloration distinguish the best of the season's decorative fabrics, which are just coming on the market. Among the rough-surfaced materials -- the vogue for which has slight precedent -- the new productions show a wide variety of ingenious weaves.

FULLY half of the American-owned paintings by Frans Hals are being assembled for the largest exclusive showing of works by the Dutch master ever held in the United States, according to announcement by Dr. William R. Valentiner, director of the Detroit Institute of Arts.

An ambulance surgeon of the Jewish Hospital in Brooklyn who had given first aid to a man who had suffered a fractured skull in an automobile accident, started back to the hospital with his patient about 6 o'clock last night. But less than a block from the original crash, at Eastern Parkway and Franklin Avenue, the ambulance was overturned in a collision with a passenger car.

ON Wednesday Democratic members of the next House of Representatives will meet in caucus to choose their candidate for Speaker to succeed the late Henry T. Rainey of Illinois. Nomination by the caucus will be equivalent to election.

WITH Japan setting the final midnight of 1936 for the requiem upon the world's first treaty limiting the perils and burdens of competitive warship building, what prospect is there for the nations except a return to the old system of build-as-build-can?

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 28. -- With cotton all picked, corn in the crib, meat in the smokehouse and butter in the Spring, the South this year found Santa Claus had confirmed the beneficences of the New Deal Merchants and manufacturers and middle men participated in the largess of a rejuvenated condition in Dixie and lagniappe overflowed in the shape of bonuses to clerks and workers in many Southern cities.

VIENNA, Dec. 29 -- Two tragic shadows mark Southeastern Europe's 1934 history. Both Austria's leader, Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, and Yugoslavia's unifier, King Alexander, died for political ideals; but the assassins did not succeed in either instance in destroying the work of their victims.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The candidacy of Representative William B. Bankhead of Alabama for the House Democratic leadership gained substantially today but his opponents contended his prediction of victory was too optimistic.

BOSTON, Dec. 27. -- The old Quincy House at Brattle Square and Brattle Street, closed since 1919, is to come down. Erected in 1819, the first building in the city to be constructed in part of Quincy granite, it has been a landmark for several generations.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 27. -- If the "Committee of Forty-nine," which has been wrestling with the problem of how Utah shall handle the sale of hard liquor, does not keep the 1935 Utah Legislature busy, the "Committee of Nice" will give the lawmakers topics enough to occupy their spare time.

NEW YORK has become conscious of the Winter weekend. Where once the townsman hugged the radiator from Friday to Monday and talked dolefully about the weather man's reports, now in constantly increasing numbers he goes blithely into the country as to a Summer picnic.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- Improving conditions in 1934 have brought a better outlook for agriculture, automobile and merchandising that should pay handsome dividends for the States of Wisconsin, Illinois and Indiana during at least half the new year.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29. -- A Leningrad firing squad today ended the lives of fourteen asserted anti-Stalin terrorists convicted of plotting and carrying out on Dec. 1 the assassination of Sergei Kiroff, who was a member of the powerful Communist Political Bureau.

THIS business of writing an airplane review of the year in the theatre is becoming so increasingly difficult that this, third of the series, may easily be the last. (Were those cheers, offstage, boy?) As life adjusts itself to the alphabetical combinations of the New Deal the violent contrasts which made the first article compose itself have smoothed themselves out, till this year and last seem as alike as stage twins.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Nine million persons will share in a dividend distribution of $140,000,000 to be completed Monday as savings, building and loan associations allocate their last six months' earnings. These were the totals contained in a report made public today by Morton Bodfish, executive vice president of the United States Building and Loan League.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Dec. 27. -- Wyoming is getting ready to take over State relief administration, should the Federal Government decide to relinquish or diminish its relief burden after the first of the year. A recent estimate by State Relief Director Robert W. Beasley indicates that approximately 27,000 of Wyoming's 232,000 population will be on relief rolls by January, 1935.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Conversations with Canada on modification of the St. Lawrence waterway treaty are to be sought by this country.

JUST as countless tributes were paid Goethe on the centenary of his death, two years ago, so solemn homage was paid to Schiller on the 175th anniversary of his birth on Nov. 10. At Berlin Minister Goebbels delivered before the League of German Authors a great address that was broadcast over all the networks.

THE American public school as originally conceived assumed a homogeneous population, similar in ideals, social usages and linguistic inheritance. As it progressively met by groups widely differing in ideals of life, given to conflicting social usages and family life, and diversified by racial and linguistic inheritances, antagonisms and interests, it began to lose its power.

Polo had as its high mark during the season of 1934 a resumption of the East-West matches, with the East regaining the championship it had lost in the first of these contests, held during 1933 in Chicago. A young East team won this year's series, played at the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L.I., in two straight games.

Strength continued yesterday in the markets for commodity futures, with trading large for a half-session. All active staples made moderate gains. In the cash markets lard reached another high mark, and rubber went up. All the grains were lower.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Dec. 29. -- The alibi which Bruno Richard Hauptmann is expected to advance at his murder trial, which begins here next Wednesday, to account for his whereabouts the day that Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was kidnapped, will be attacked by a surprise witness for the State, it was learned today from a source close to the prosecution.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Dec. 29 (AP). -- How speeds of 132,000 revolutions a minute and more generating forces 900,000 times that of gravity have been obtained in the Rouss Physical Laboratory at the University of Virginia by means of rotors in a vacuum chamber was explained today to the American Physical Society.

PALM BEACH -- With the increase in length of the Palm Beach season, extended gradually from two to five months in recent years, this resort begins the New Year anticipating a full measure of activity. Colonists began arriving in October, thus initiating a Winter season that promises to outdo even the extravagant early prophecies of size and brilliance.

THOUGH the year 1935 will bring its share of trials, its approach has been accompanied by some brightening of the horizons, which lately have been so dark. In the United States the President's hand has been strengthened by a national vote of confidence and in Europe there has been a notable, because quite unexpected, relaxation of tension.

A SPATE of novelties has characterized the Autumn season now ending. The Courtauld-Sargent concerts have introduced a new suite for viola by Vaughan Williams. Three movements of William Walton's new symphony were played at the last London Symphony Orchestra concert.

WHEN John Nance Garner, Vice President of the United States, returned to the capital recently he spoke of himself as "just a country boy trying to get along with city slickers," and said that such a one feels "like a jack rabbit when the dogs get after him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A reputed Communist plot to kidnap the President and an alleged Fascist scheme to set up a dictatorship were made public today by the House Committee which has been investigating un-American activities.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Childhood is no longer devouring glamourous fairy-tale books, but is turning instead to realistic stories of a modern age. Where their parents found delight in "Beauty and the Beast," when they were small, today's children demand "Mr. Brown's Grocery Store."

AS enthusiasm for Winter sports increases, the shops turn to the Northern countries for inspiration. Norway, the Austrian Tyrol and Northern Scotland all contribute to make our Winter outfits a success. Even the garments worn by polar explorers inspire attractive hoods or coats.
The nine Neediest Cases published on these pages are typical tragedies of distress selected from many cases which still await relief.

WHETHER the advantages of kingship counterbalance the disadvantages may in most cases be open to argument. The sense of power, the subservience of every person to the ruler, the pomp and luxury of a monarch's surroundings may perhaps compensate him for the ceremonial, the rigid time-table and the necessity of maintaining at all times the expected "regal dignity."

IN the present stage of the dance in America those mystic words "important" and "significant" are perhaps less applicable to accomplishments in art than to accomplishments in organization. It is therefore gratifying be able to report two projects that belong to the second category, one of them new and the other an expansion of an old project.

THE situation pertaining to both the domestic and foreign affairs of Germany continues interesting and important. The fires of revolution in the Fatherland have been smoldering throughout the post-war period; and it is well known that rulers often provoke controversies with foreign peoples to divert the attention of their own subjects from revolutionary enterprises.

MRS. HOPKINSON has appended to her story of "Anne of England" the subtitle, "The Biography of a Great Queen." Not many persons -- at least before reading this book -- would be inclined to agree with Mrs. Hopkinson's verdict.

THE dispute between the Actors Equity Association and theatre managers over the desirability of Sunday theatrical performances in New York has again brought up the question of what the city can do to amuse itself on the first day of the week.

WHAT is said to be the first complete and authoritative history of the Nazis in any language is announced for publication late in January by Alfred A. Knopf. The title of the book is "A History of National Socialism," and the author is Konrad Heiden, who was a student of law and politics at the University of Munich in 1920.

APPARENTLY tired of the frequent citing by Paul Joseph Goebbels, the Nazi propaganda chief, of "Potemkin" as a work to be imitated, if possible, by the coordinated German motion picture makers, Sergei M. Eisenstein, the director of the great Russian naval film, recently wrote an open letter to Dr. Goebbels.
PALMA, Majorca, Dec. 12. -- Americans stranded in the Balearic Islands, without funds and without friends to provide for them, constitute a serious problem for the Provincial Government.

Max Baer brought the world's heavyweight championship back to America after an interval of a year. That was the big thing in twelve months of boxing that started disappointingly and gradually worked up to a highly successful period -- one that, under the prevailing economic conditions, compared favorably with the boom times of former years.

The shattering of Johnny Weissmuller's 10-year-old record for the 100-meter free style by Peter Fick of the New York A.C. and the unexpectedly fine showing made during a visit to Japan by three of our swimming champions -- Jack Medica of Seattle, Albert Vande Weghe of Paterson, N.J., and Arthur Highland of Chicago -- were highlights of American water sports in 1934.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Mrs. John J. Farrell of Darien, Conn., and Mrs. Julius Bliss of Bronxville, N.Y., shared honors today in the Saxon Woods Hunt Club's Horse Show, which attracted a large field from the surrounding area.

Harold G. Hoffman, Motor Vehicle Commissioner of New Jersey, and Governor-elect, issued a statement yesterday urging the automobile companies to make safety "one of the dominant factors in the advertising of the 1935 models."
New champions were established in both court tennis and racquets during the season of 1938-1934.

Ways and means of reaching agreement on a legislative program and general policies to rehabilitate the Republican party in this State will be discussed at a conference of Republican county chairmen and members of the Legislature in the Ten Eyck Hotel at Albany on Jan. 8 on the call of State Chairman Melvin C. Eaton.
Since we face the possibility of another war it is important to note what, if anything, is being done to protect the lives of soldiers.

JAPANESE flower arrangement, which claims, according to tradition, a history of some 1,200 years, is represented by a large number of different "schools." The writer is familiar with more than thirty. The two that she has studied particularly for the last ten years are the Koryu and the Ohara-ryu -- "Old School" and "Ohara School."

The promised threat of the Mid-western stars in the national junior indoor tennis championship became a reality yesterday when two entrants from Northwestern University advanced to the semi-final round.

Competing in his first Grand American Handicap. richest and most important of all trapshooting competitions, Lawrence George Dana, 58-year-old oil producer from Derrick City, Pa., gained the highest honors in his sport during the past season.

Outstanding in yachting during the past year was the America's Cup match off Newport in which the New York Yacht Club defender Rainbow, sailed by Harold S. Vanderbilt, defeated T.O.M. Sopwith's challenger Endeavour, from the Royal Yacht Squadron of Cowes, England, four races to two.

REVIVAL of interest in the etchings of Samuel Palmer to such an extent as has recently taken place would be astonishing were it not for the doctrine of averages, in art as in everything; a doctrine with which old-timers become familiar after succumbing with normal frequency to the unfounded astonishments.

PLANS for old-age security have been widely discussed of late. It is natural that in trying to analyze problems of unemployment and relief those leaving, rather than those entering, the normal period of self-maintenance and support of families should be set aside for special treatment.

Although no international matches enlivened the year's field hockey schedule, there was hardly a dearth of interest or ability on local or national fields. Successful sectional tournaments were conducted by the Northeast at Garden City, L.I.; the Southeast at Washington, the Great Lakes at Cleveland, the Midwest at Madison, Wis., and the Pacific Coast at Berkeley.

Largely through the tireless efforts of young Peter Fick, the New York Athletic Club annexed top honors in the first major swimming meet of the season, a quadrangular contest in the 75-foot Winged Foot pool, last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- For the second time during the three-day meeting of the American Astronomical Society here at the Franklin Institute the new star which recently appeared in the constellation of Hercules was one of the chief objects of discussion.

Captain Robert G. Malin, commodore of the Cunard fleet since September, 1931, and master of the Samaria, has retired at the age limit of 60 after being thirty-four years in the company's North Atlantic service.

THE electrical flood of symphony and opera into the 8 o'clock hour on Sunday nights has caused many a listener, who feasts on classical music, to request that at least two of the broadcasts be spread on the clock. It seems the radio listener feels he should be able to hear everything that goes on the air if he chooses.
The first and most important resolution for 1935 for every resident of the city should be to lead a life which will insure good health, Health Commissioner John L. Rice said yesterday.

THE economic depression in the United States has had ramifications in British Honduras. A forest industry of major importance to that Central American country -- the gathering of chicle, the milky juice of the tropical sapodilla tree, which is used as a base in the manufacture of chewing gum -- has been adversely affected, according to a report by Sir Alan Pim, British Commissioner appointed to investigate the financial and economic condition of the colony.

MR. MACKAYE has written a lively cycle of municipal shenanigans that might be called The Ring of the Walkerie. His "Tin Box Parade" begins with the decline of Murphy and ends soon after the fall of Curry.

As emphasizing the remarkable vitality of the bond market, the statistical record now being completed is particularly interesting. It shows that bond transactions in 1934 were the heaviest in ten years, while stock trading was the slowest in that period. The total bond volume on the New York Stock Exchange approximated $3,720,520,000, compared with $3,366,402,950 in 1933 and with $4,098,696,027 in 1922, which was the biggest bond year in history.

LIKE its theme, modern art, "Expressionism in Art" bears the stamp of the "modern temper" -- that is, a temper which seems incapable of moderation, of following the difficult via media, but one which must needs oscillate from one extreme to the other.

Intercollegiate football furnished the complete retort in 1934 to those who have pictured it as moribund and losing its hold on the public's fancy. On at least four counts it can look back upon the past season as one of the most robustly satisfying campaigns since Princeton and Rutgers started the ball rolling in 1869.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29. -- Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was today elected president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
The championship situation among the heavyweight wrestlers was clarified considerably during 1934. Where the close of 1933 saw five claimants to the world's crown, the field is now reduced to two.

Mexican fresh green peas made their first appearance of the season here the last of the week, it was said yesterday in the weekly review of the wholesale markets issued by the State Department of Agriculture and Markets. Two carloads arrived and were disposed of at wholesale at from $4 to $4.50 a crate of about thirty pounds and at from $4 to $4.25 a bushel hamper.

PARIS. A RECORD crowd of smart Parisiennes is off to the holiday Winter sports. The majority head for St. Moritz, where the Palace offers every attraction and distraction -- indoors as well as out. Not the least is the new private flying field.
RYE, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Led by Captain Paul Guibord. who tallied [four goals, the Dartmouth hockey team tonight conquered Colgate by a score of 8 -- 1 at the Playland Rink.

At a meeting of the Rowing Coaches Organization of America yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, plans were discussed for putting on a permanent basis the association formed informally at Poughkeepsie last June.

Broadening of the scope of lectures and courses at the New School for Social Research was noted yesterday by Dr. Alvin Johnson, its director, in a review of the school's work and an announcement of the Spring program.

"The Downfall of European Liberalism" is the title of a long and interesting article in the Literary Supplement of The London Times. The writer makes out a plausible case for himself by going back to the days when the Liberal party in Great Britain was flourishing like a green bay tree and when, on the Continent, the Liberal movement was making headway in Italy and France.

An international flavor was given the soccer season of 1934 by the visit of the Sport Klub Kladno from Czechoslovakia, which played eight matches in New York, Chicago, St. Louis and Cleveland, winning six and losing two. One of the defeats sustained by the tourists was within the metropolitan area, the Metropolitan All-Stars nosing them out by 3 -- 2.

Problems confronting the League of Nations will be discussed during the week of Jan. 7 at a League of Nations School to be held in The Herald Tribune conference room, 230 West Forty-first Street, under the auspices of the New York Branch of the League of Nations Association.

MADISON, N.J., Dec. 29. -- After fifty-six years of commuting on the Lackawanna Railroad, a record in this community, William Webb Davis, 73 years old, of 30 Hillside Avenue, will make his last trip to New York as a regular commuter Monday. He will then retire as a salesman for the United States Alcohol Company.

Mrs. Ramsay Pengnet of Bronxville, N.Y., presented the youngest daughter, Miss Virginia Nathalie Peugnet, at a tea dance yesterday at the National Society of Colonial Dames house, 215 East Seventy-first Street. The debutante is a great-granddaughter of Hyacinth Peugnet, a high ranking officer in Napoleon's Guard, who, in recognition of his services, received the title of Baron.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- The promise of an unusually active Winter season here is seen in the fact that in the Autumn season, just closed, a population double that of any similar period came to Sea Island Beach. The Winter calendar of sports, recreation and social activities has been drawn up to provide daily features.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29. -- The City College basketball team, after leading at half-time, lost the second of its two-game trip to Duquesne tonight. 40 -28. Last night Coach Nat Holman's five bowed to Geneva.

The Midwestern section of the country made a clean sweep of the major bowling titles during the past year as the sport again enjoyed a season of intense competition. Huge turnouts once more appeared for tournaments of any consequence and, as always has been the case, the American Bowling Congress topped them all in the matter of entries.

The skeleton of a whale, the largest of its kind that has ever been scientifically recorded, has just been placed on public exhibition by the American Museum of Natural History after spending more than a quarter of a century in the storerooms and preparations department of the museum.
RYE, N.Y.,Dec. 29. -- Westchester County will celebrate an unusually gay New Year's Eve, according to the advance reservations at the country clubs.
Rifle shooting during the past year was marked by the establishment of several world's records and by continued high standards of marksmanship on the part of American shots.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP). -- The new leisure arising from shorter hours should be used to "make America literate," says a Federal education expert.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 29.--At least three official attempts to secure municipal consolidation or regional reorganization of local government functions in New Jersey for purposes of economy and efficiency have failed in the last two years.

PARIS, Dec. 29. -- The French Foreign Office last evening sent to Rome the final French proposals on the maintenance of the status quo in Central Europe, on which all the Franco-Italian negotiations have hinged. It was said that if an agreement could be reached on this point Foreign Minister Pierre Laval would visit Rome early in January for final conversations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A prediction that the government would issue no more tax-exempt securities was made today by Senator Ashurst, chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the upper chamber.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- American Methodists, 9,000,000 of them, will be joined tomorrow and Monday in a nation-wide celebration climaxing a year-long observance of the sesquicentennial of the "Constitutional Convention" of American Methodism in 1784.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 27. -- Alabama's thirty-ninth Governor will become her forty-first on Jan. 14, and as Montgomery prepares for the biggest inaugural celebration in years, contrast is sharp between the circumstances in which Bibb Graves finds himself today and those in which he found himself prior to his first inaugural in 1927.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 29. -- Alabama and Stanford burned their football bridges behind them today with their conflict, the twentieth annual Rose Tournament game, three days away.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Describing the AAA as "the most brilliant success yet achieved by the Roosevelt administration," Professor Allan Nevins of Columbia University devoted his recent fifth New Deal lecture at University College to farm policy.

The Attorney General's conference on crime has met and adjourned, and it is a little disappointing that nothing was said regarding public education in its relation to crime prevention. This omission is the more disquieting at a time when education is so harassed by shortage of funds and when newspapers contain so many stories of criminal outrages.
BERLIN, Dec. 29. -- Germany's economic situation as this year ends is better than most of her critics predicted, better even than many Germans expected.

NEW YORK'S thirty-fifth annual automobile show will open at the Grand Central Palace next Saturday afternoon, and, skipping Sunday, continue through the following week. Several hundred individual cars and chassis, representing twenty-eight makes of passenger automobiles and six commercial vehicles, will be on display, as well as a large assortment of accessory and equipment items.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Dec. 29. -- Jay F. Carlisle of East Islip once more took the leading honors in the retriever trials of the Brookhaven Game Protective Association at Strong's Neck in East Setauket.

Opening of Congress Thursday will signal the start of a protracted struggle for enactment of laws altering present foreign trade regulations, according to programs worked out last week by domestic manufacturers, exporters and importers.

With Hortense Monath as soloist, the Schumann piano concerto made its seasonal re-entry in the program lists of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at last night's Students Concert in Carnegie Hall, conducted by Bruno Waiter. The pianist was rousingly applauded after a performance of technical competence and an adequate scale of dynamics, though not conspicuous for romantic warmth or lyric persuasiveness.

THE recent solution of the Saar problem auspiciously reached at Rome may possibly render several books on Hitler's Third Reich superfluous. But not this one. The phenomenon, in its militaristic, ethnic, religious and economic phases has been entertainingly, if not decisively, interpreted by more or less authoritative exponents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- John Paul Chase, one of the few remaining members of the Dillinger gang of outlaws, was held tonight by the Department of Justice on a charge of murder as a confederate of the late George (Baby Face) Nelson in a gun fight at Barrington, Ill., on Nov. 27 in which Inspector Samuel P. Cowley and Herman E. Hollis, a Federal special agent, were killed.

AND now it is S.M. Chartook, a young impresario, who will attempt the devious routes of the road, disturbing the dust raised only on occasion by Miss Cornell and similar wanderers. His fare will be Gilbert and Sullivan -- fittingly enough, since it was he who, after the passing of Milton Aborn, took charge last Spring of the Aborn company here and in Boston. . . .

Trade continued active in the wholesale and manufacturing divisions in the metropolitan area last week, according to the weekly survey prepared especially for THE TIMES by the New York Credit Men's Association, under the direction of John F. Otis, assistant secretary.
On the last Sunday of the year, the fund for New York's Neediest Cases reached $218,796.66, when 104 persons added $1,608 to the previous total.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Dec. 27. -- An obstacle to enacting a law to provide Kansas with a State police system was removed when the powerful Peace Officers Association endorsed the plan, and it is now practically certain that the Legislature will vote to establish the system.

KANGAROO COURT is a little-known prisoners' institution that operates in the majority of county jails. Sheriffs and jail wardens usually deny its existence, but penologists are familiar with it, and men who have been subjected to its rule speak of such experiences only after they have escaped its sinister jurisdiction.

Construction of the Sixth Avenue subway line of the city's independent subway system will begin at once if and when the city obtains the $310,000,000 in Federal funds it is seeking for a public works program, Mayor La Guardia revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Plans for the next year's Pacific war games of the United States Navy revealed at Los Angeles are in harmony with the announcement made several months ago by Secretary of the Navy Claude A. Swanson that the 1935 manoeuvres would ContLuued on Page Fourteem

BERLIN, Dec. 29.--Another outspoken American girl is under arrest in the small frontier town of Waldmohr in the Palatinate, where Germany adjoins the Saar, apparently for an expression of opinion characterized as "derogatory" to Chancellor Hitler.

Japan has no "immediate intentions" toward the Philippines and does not want "to grab" the islands, Francisco Afan Delgado, new Philippine Resident Commissioner in the United States, declared yesterday at the Hotel Astor. Mr. Delgado arrived in Houston, Texas, from the Philippines Dec. 23 and came to New York on his way to Washington where he will take up his duties when Congress opens this week.

AN overwhelmingly Democratic Congress, elected last November, will meet on Thursday of this week to take stock of the present situation, to air its views and to enact legislation in matters of profound importance to the country.
Roland M. Jones wrote thus of Nebraska's unicameral Legislature:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Nine Governors and Governors-elect, twenty-seven Mayors, fifty-eight churchmen, fifty-four college presidents and professors and 109 lawyers, editors, writers, jurists and other distinguished citizens have joined in signing a memorial addressed to President Roosevelt urging that in his opening address to Congress he place the Costigan-Wagner Anti-Lynching Bill on his "must" program.

While numerous price advances loom in the textile industries during the coming month, buyers will have been protected sufficiently on initial requirements to eliminate any change in early Spring goods by retailers, it was agreed here yesterday in the local selling market.

Appointment of Thomas L. Ennis as general counsel of the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation to succeed H.T. Newcomb, vice president and general counsel, who is about to retire, was announced yesterday by L.F. Loree, president. The change will take place on Wednesday.

PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Dartmouth College got off to an excellent start in the defense of the President Harding Trophy, symbolic of the team prize for the Lake Placid Sno Birds' College Week Winter sports competition, when it scored heavily in the 14-kilometer cross-country race and the slalom contest as the fourteenth annual games started today.

NINE years ago Katharine Cornell was wearing the slouch green hat in the service of Michael Arlen's sniveling balderdash. Now she is playing Juliet. That bare statement of fact very nearly epitomizes the rise of a great actress in America.

WHEN 53,000 copies of a new book are sold in the British Isles on the day of publication, the reputation of its author may be regarded as well established. For "sold," in such a case, does not mean purchased by customers over the counter but bought by the bookstores in full confidence that their investment will be justified by the public demand.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Dec. 29. -- The United Anthracite miners of Pennsylvania, insurgent union, reached their objective here today when operations at the Glen Alden Coal Company's collieries were practically at a standstill as a result of a strike in protest of alleged wage reductions and discrimination.

THE African Violet, too rarely seen, puts in a brief appearance at this time of year, when florists stock flowering plants for the holiday season. It is a species that has much to commend it as a house plant; and it is entirely different from other dependable house plants.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27. -- Los Angeles and Southern California are enjoying a recess from trials and tribulation following a holiday trading season the like of which has not been known here since 1929-30. Many of the larger stores are almost literally sold out.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Following are the diplomatic interchange and statements made public here today on the occasion of the denunciation by Japan of the Washington naval treaty of 1922:

OTTAWA, Ont., Dec. 29. -- The Bank of Canada, the Dominion's new central bank created by act of Parliament last session, will not begin operation until March 1. A start in January had been hoped for, but the task of printing and signing the notes of the bank, which eventually will provide the only legal tender for Canada aside from token money, proved too great.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to extend for two years a 6 per cent note for $6,700,000 held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and maturing on Feb. 27.

Bridge players have apparently reached the stage where a dictator is needed. The officials of one of the bridge "leagues" have posted a notice that only certain specified systems will be permitted at their tournaments. The first repercussion is the threat of damage suits by writers whose systems have been excluded.
FRANKSTON, Australia, Dec. 29. -- About 15,000 spectators and Boy Scouts from many nations, including the United States, attended the opening today of the International Boy Scouts' Jamboree.

PARIS, Dec. 22. -- French women are preparing to make a resolute fight for suffrage at the next session of Parliament. Their prospects are much better than ever before owing to better organization and the fact that many leading politicians have been won over to their cause.

Most of us think of mass in terms of weight. NEWTON defined mass as quantity of matter. The definition is meaningless. Hence the notion of inertia was invoked to make "mass" clearer. How much force does it take to bring ten freight cars from rest to a speed of twenty miles an hour in fifteen minutes?

The grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria was the scene last night of an entertainment that had many of the characteristics of the dances which have been attended so enthusiastically during the holidays by the hundreds of young persons in town for the school and college vacation period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Legislation calling for United States membership in the League of Nations is being drafted by State Department experts, it was reliably reported tonight, simultaneously with announcement by Senator Pope that he would introduce a resolution to that effect in the Senate soon after it meets.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- With its tourist population greatly swelled by the holiday rush, St. Petersburg made ready to welcome New Year's with a round of dances and parties. A midnight party will welcome in young 1935 at the Soreno and the Dragon Club's annual New Year's ball at the Vinoy Park will be attended by many in society.

WHO is Agee, what is he, that by jacket and foreword Stephen Vincent Benet and Archibald MacLeish commend him? He is a new poet with a fine, skillful talent. In his lines there is awareness of the changing ideas of society that are stirring the world.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29.--President and Mrs. Roosevelt gave a dinner dance tonight at the White House for their sons, Franklin D. Jr. and John, and for Miss Barbara Cushing, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Cushing, and Miss Jean Martineau, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyril Martineau.

An orphaned baby girl, adopted a few months ago by a childless English couple, is the heiress to an estate of $8,737 left by her mother, it was disclosed yesterday through records of the Surrogates' Court. The baby's foster parents do not know of the existence of the estate, it was said, and it will presumably pile up until the child comes of age in 1954.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Sixty years of study of the continental ice sheets which formerly covered the greater part of New York State were reported to the Geological Society of America today by Dr. Herman Leroy Fairchild, 84 years old, University of Rochester Professor Emeritus of Geology.

BOGOTA, Dec. 29. -- President Alfonso Lopez today decreed an indefinite prolongation of the special session of Congress called for consideration of the Rio de Janeiro pact providing for settlement of the Leticia dispute with Peru.

Lily Pons in "Lucia" 'and Frederick Jagel in "Faust'' led the last groups of reappearing artists in the season's opening week at the Metropolitan yesterday. The two operas, by' coincidence, had been those first sung on the same stage fifty-two years ago.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- The growth of the economic crisis in France has brought a corresponding intensification in the "Buy France" campaign which is being fostered by nationalistically minded manufacturers. One of the leaders in this campaign, the magazine L'Usine, an organ of French heavy industries, has just issued its version of what should constitute a "French" product.

AN exhibition of "Master Drawings," selected from museums and private collections in this country, will open with a private view next Thursday evening at the Albright Art Gallery in Buffalo. The handsome catalogue, in which all of the 132 drawings are illustrated, can leave no doubt in one's mind as to the exhibition's superb quality.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- As the Treasury Department took steps today to put into effect Tuesday its regulations providing that liquor bottles and even containers used by retail liquor venders shall bear blown-in stamps, Ammon McClellan, executive head of the League of Distilled Spirits Rectifiers, asserted that 90,000,000 bottles would have to be destroyed at a loss of $3,500,000 to the industry.

HALIFAX, N.S., Dec. 27. -- Nova Scotia has a Dayton case. Clergymen of two religious denominations have united in protest to the Provincial Government against alleged modernistic teachings contained in the history books used in Nova Scotia's high schools.

Before the new year is four days old, another motor-boating season will have been launched, with the first of the long sequence of meetings for yacht owners, speed-boat skippers, shipbuilders and brokers from then until the National Motor Boat Show closes, Jan. 26.

Fencing in the United States last season had an international tinge for the first time since the Olympic Games of 1932 as this ancient sport continued to thrive with one of its finest campaigns in many years.

WITH the new year struggling at this moment over the Battery wall on its chase to Broadway, it seems a fair time for an experiment. Every now and then letters have arrived at the headquarters of these columns urging that some reference be made to the plays that opened the week before.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Mgr. Raymond A. Kearney of Brooklyn was named today as Auxiliary Bishop of Brooklyn, becoming assistant to Bishop Thomas E. Malloy. He was given the titular designation of Bishop of Lisinia. Lisinia was once a diocese in the Pamphilia Region of Asia Minor.

BOSTON, Dec. 29. -- If youth will discard the "superstition of individualism" and turn to social planning along lines the machine age makes possible, it may for the first time in history live in harmony with its ideals, Edward A. Filene, Boston merchant, told members of the National Student Federation at their tenth annual congress here today.

TO write the story of the Queenstown Command, which day and night carried on a campaign against the German submarines off the southwest coast of Ireland in the World War, only a sailor and one who served under Admiral Sir Lewis Bayly could qualify.

PITTSBURG, Kan., Dec. 29 (AP). -- The fatal shooting of P. Louis Zickgraf, well-known Pittsburg lawyer, provided authorities here today with a mystery rivaling that of a detective magazine thriller, "Murder on the Limited," which the lawyer had been reading when he met death last night.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 29. -- Invading skippers and boats led the Long Islanders today in the sailing dinghy races on Manhasset Bay. William B. Dodge of Mystic, Conn., was high-point scorer in Class A with his craft Moth Ball, and Frank E. Campbell of Larchmont made the top total in Class B with his boat Fancy Pants, which he had out for the first time this Winter.

LONDON, Dec. 29.--The opinion held jointly by the United States and British naval delegations tonight is that while Japan's denunciation of the Washington Treaty is a most deplorable setback for naval limitation, it is better to have the thing over and done with, instead of hanging fire as a mere threat from Tokyo.

THE fun of having a Winter garden need not be forfeited by those who have only very little space available. Miniature gardens -- which may be so small as to repose on a single narrow window-sill -- are becoming more and more popular.

Dr. Robert Underwood Johnson, director of the Hall of Fame, announced yesterday that the eighth quinquennial election of distinguished Americans to the Hall, on the campus of New York University, would be held in 1935.

A square-rigged sailing ship with tall spars and rolling canvas is due off Quarantine this morning after a voyage that followed the route of Columbus and which will be continued in part on the route followed by Magellan for a circumnavigation of the earth.

MOST of the Winter damage to plants occurs after the turn of the year. The usual "January thaw," which may not come until February or early March, is often responsible for much of it. Therefore gardeners who have learned from experience that it does not pay to take chances give protection to those plants which are most subject to injury.

On Sunday, Dec. 31, of last year announcement was made of contributions to the Neediest Cases Fund amounting to $218,767.98. On this corresponding Sunday -- with still an intervening day before the end of the year -- the total has already passed that total by a very slight margin, the amount to date being $218,796.66.

While the continued activity on the Stock Exchange yesterday encouraged the commission houses, it was recalled that there often is some enlargement in activity on a Saturday preceding the year-end. On the corresponding day of last year the volume was 751,000 shares, or about 9,000 less than yesterday Market interests found more comfort in the fact that delayed "tax selling" was absorbed easily and that the general list of stocks continued to move ahead.

BRUNO WALTER will conduct "A Faust Overture," the preludes to Acts I and III of "Lohengrin" and the entire first act of "Die Walkuere" this afternoon at the third and last of the series of all-Wagner concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony under his direction at Carnegie Hall.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Dec. 29 (AP). -- A1 Kruger of Beloit, Wis.,, with a 70, two under par, took the lead in the California $1,500 open golf tournament today.

WHEN Winter grips the Netherlands those hardy skaters, the Frisians, go whirling through their eleven towns, with their arms revolving like windmills, on their annual 125-mile race. And every year, as suitable conditions for this event are awaited, the question, Where are the Winters of yesteryear? crops up, not only in Friesland but all over Holland.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- A throng of mourners, including many friends of John E. Andrus, financier, in business, finance, politics and other activities, attended a funeral service for him at the Andrus residence at 165 Hudson Terrace, here, today.

LONDON, Dec. 19. -- Stanley Baldwin today is the man who speaks the mind of the British people. To him, to his utterances, we have to turn if we wish to understand British mentality in home, as well as in foreign, affairs. Now, with regard to the latter, Mr. Baldwin within the last twelve months has said two things which are essential.

It has always required a certain amount of effort to grow sentimental concerning New Year's Day. After all, what is there old that is really rung out and what is there new that is really rung in at midnight of Dec. 31? The important dates in the routine of our lives do not include Jan. 1.

A BRILLIANTLY gifted musician and writer about music was lost when Hubbard Hutchinson of THE TIMES music department died of lymphatic leukemia on the evening of Christmas Day. Grace and sensitiveness of style, quick intuitions and enthusiasm for the art he loved were conspicuous attributes of his writing.

BERLIN, Dec. 29. -- Reichsbishop Ludwig Mueller will end his year's campaign for absolute rule of the Protestant Church in Germany without either authority or followers. He has been forced to rescind all his decrees, reconstitute the independent provincial churches and reinstate his most vigorous opponents.

WITH "the largest number of advance orders" in their history, the various divisions of the Chrysler Corporation have announced increased production to new record highs. Plymouth, De Soto, Chrysler and Dodge cars are included in production schedules aggregating nearly 3,000 cars a day.

A COURIER from the Astoria front dashed into Times Square last week with a bulletin relating to the second Ben Hecht-Charles MacArthur picture, "Once in a Blue Moon," which used to be called "Laugh Little Clown." Nothing having been heard of the opus since the master filmmakers left the Ramapo Hills last Summer and filed notice that the picture was completed, the courier was welcomed with due formality and asked what intelligence he carried.
ROME, Dec. 29. -- The Franco-Italian agreement, in addition to a guarantee of Austria's independence, is expected to include the following points:

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Henry A. Wallace, Secretary of Agriculture, today told the American Association for the Advancement of Science that this country may be entering a century-long period of rise in prices and may not return to the gold standard.

THE quickie is a motion picture made in Poverty Row on a shoestring; the creature on the double bill the neighborhood movie is ashamed to advertise. Until the arrival of the talking pictures the quickie had a fighting chance to make a profit.

OTTAWA, Dec. 28. -- Sir Maurice Hankey, perpetual and lately peripatetic secretary to all British Cabinets, has spent six days in Ottawa and departed for London without revealing publicly the object of his four-month tour of the British Empire.

Swinging into stride with a rousing second-half rally, the New York University quintet increased its two-year winning streak to twenty straight last night with a 25-18 victory over Notre Dame in the grand finale to a college double-header in Madison Square Garden.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Only a narrow street separates the training camps of Temple and Tulane tonight, as the principals in the New Year's Sugar Bowl battle make final preparations for their intersectional clash.

THE nine chapters which make up the body of this book, all of them, with one exception, previously published as magazine articles, fall into two groups, the first relating to the present struggle in this country between capital and labor and the second to certain political tendencies attributed to the New Deal.

SAARBRUCKEN, Dec. 29. -- Charges that a concentration camp for prominent Saar anti-Nazis has been established at Neunkirchen are made today in a sworn statement by Wilhelm Fischer, former welfare secretary of the Nazi German Front.

ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- Thirty-seven years' experience as police magistrate and children's court judge have convinced Judge John J. Brady that "old-fashioned home life" is the best antidote for domestic difficulties and juvenile delinquency.

BERLIN, Dec. 2. AT no period within record has the German theatre drawn its dramatic fare from the classics of stage literature as it does this season. Unfortunately, it is not always the stoutness of quality which prompts this unstinting cutback. Since political rhetoric keeps the Fatherland's air vibrating unceasingly, the stage, too, must lift a robust voice if it wants to be heard.

The children's health service of the New York Diet Kitchen Association will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Parsifal" the afternoon of Jan. 12 at the Metropolitan Opera House, which has been taken over by the board of managers of the organization to raise funds for the protection of mothers and children.

Defending team champions, notably those boasting long reigns, encountered powerful opposition in the city P.S.A.L. senior high school sports ranks during the year. Most of the 1933 titleholders were toppled, among them Curtis High, which had ruled the cross-country paths for six straight seasons.

Fifty delegates from thirty-five professional organizations in this city met yesterday afternoon in the Russell Sage Foundation and discussed their relation to the Congress on Unemployment and Social Insurance to be held in Washington from Jan. 5 to 7.

There was a time, as Science Service reminds us, when "Uncle Sam was rich enough to give us all a farm" -- and not mere little plots of laud, but whole farms. The original homesteaders got them outright, either "scot-free" or for a nominal sum per acre.
THE year 1934 has been both interesting and productive in aeronautics. As one glances back over the year notable events -- not all of them in the air -- stand out.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 29. -- United States Senator Huey P. Long, in a letter sent this week to W.R. Bartholomew, a resident of this city, said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The National Association of Manufacturers asserted today that "no system of unemployment insurance has any chance whatever of success unless it is on a contributory basis." This statement was contained in a study by John C. Gall, associate counsel of the association.

Although I am indebted to THE NEW YORK TIMES and to William MacDonald for the extensive and generous review of my book, "Autopsy of the Monroe Doctrine," in the Book Review for Dec. 16. I must call your attention to a misstatement in it, probably due to a printer's error, which may leave a mistaken impression with some of your readers.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- Ninety-three graduate students and seniors have been elected to the Cornell University chapter of Phi Kappa Phi, national honorary scholastic society. Scholastic achievement in any of the colleges of the university makes students eligible for this honor.

HERE is a book which makes pleasant reading and which will tell those who are casually interested a good deal about the external appearance of Guatemala and the way its people look and behave. By the same token, there could hardly be a more striking contrast than that between Agnes Rothery's approach to Latin America and that of such writers as Carleton Beals, Ernest Gruening and Anita Brenner.

The Citizens Family Welfare Committee distributed yesterday approximately $1,000,000 in checks to family welfare agencies entitled to share in the fund of more than $3,000,000 raised by the committee to help meet the needs that cannot be met by public agencies, it was announced by James G. Blaine, chairman of the committee.
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 29. -- Using eclipsing stars, one 15,000,000 times as large as the sun, two Pasadena astronomers have determined the distribution of chemical elements in a star's atmosphere.

The sixteenth annual Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating championships will be staged at Newburgh on Tuesday with an entry of 162, the largest in the history of the meet, listed to compete. The meet will be held on the six-lap course on Downing Park Lake or, if ice is not available there, on a new rink built in Roosevelt-Delano Recreation Park.

In the tropical waters of Florida last Winter speed-boat racing thundered off to one of its greatest seasons. There was no Harmsworth Trophy defended, but motor boating's international sphere reached out in 1934 and embraced the leading drivers of Europe in the most pretentious regatta ever staged in this country.
Mr. Downes's discussion in THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the proposed Philharmonic-Metropolitan merger brings to the fore some points that are of vital concern at this time to music in our country.

FIFTY-FOUR years ago Ubet was a tiny, sprawling frontier settlement in the Judith Gap country of what was then Montana Territory, and was about to emerge into the glory it was presently to attain as an important and famous station on the Fort Benton-Billings stage line.

MONTREAL. -- Sunday ski specials to the Laurentians will be inaugurated for the season by the Canadian railways today and heavy traffic is expected this morning, tomorrow and on New Year's Day, as skiing conditions, unfavorable earlier in the season, have improved owing to the recent heavy snowfall.

BONGAO, P.I., Dec. 29 (By Wireless). -- A breakdown at sea, complicated by a perilous lack of drinking water, the threat of a tumbling barometer and an outbreak of hysteria among Chinese passengers that necessitated a firm display of arms, gave the Griswold-Harkness Asiatic Expedition five bad days.

TURKS, Egyptians and Moslems of India axe beginning to choose family names, or surnames. Generally they are not a very ancient institution even in the West, starting only about nine centuries ago as a consequence of the adoption of baptismal or Christian names.

ON Aug. 27, 1933, there appeared in these columns an article called "The Sentimental Journey of an Exile" by Alfred Kerr. An editorial note preceding the article informed the reader that Mr. Kerr had been for many years the dramatic critic of the Berliner Tageblatt and that he was "one of the many Jews who are no longer free to practice their profession in Germany."

WALDMOHR, Germany, Dec. 29 -- Miss Elsa Sittell of New York, held in jail here for a week, was revealed tonight as an American Saarlander en route to vote in the Jan. 13 plebiscite, her arrest following her remark she was going to vote against the Saar territory's return to Germany.

A definite improvement in business conditions during 1935 was predicted by a preponderant majority -- 84 per cent -- of the 150 members of the Economic Credit Council of the National Association of Credit Men, according to the sixth survey of the business situation by the council released yesterday.

A NEW type of front-wheel suspension, using thin, soft springs, and redistribution of ear weight for greater passenger comfort mark the Plymouths for 1935, which will be shown to the public at the opening of the automobile show.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 29. -- L'Aiglon in the New Palm Beach Hotel was the setting tonight for a dinner dance with which Frank Kemp Quigley entertained his school and college friends, who were seated at one long, flower- adorned table on the west loggia.

BOSTON, Dec. 28. BOSTON discovered two shiny new plays in its Christmas stocking. One of them, Robert E. Sherwood's "The Petrified Forest," opening on the eve of the holiday at the Shubert, found a crowded house to greet it in spite of the long-standing tradition that tree trimming at home or carol singing on Beacon Hill shall be the only Bostonian occupations of that evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Leo J. Keena of Detroit, consul general in Paris, has been appointed secretary in the diplomatic service and designated counselor of embassy there. He will serve in this capacity in addition to Theodore Marriner, the present counselor, under an arrangement requiring two counselors because of a consolidation of administrative work of the embassy and the consulate general, designed to make for close cooperation and increased efficiency.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- A new pamphlet on passive defense against air attacks is being circulated through the newspaper kiosks, where it can be bought for 50 centimes, or a little more than 3 cents. Bearing on its front page the official designation: "Prefecture of Police; General Bureau for Passive Defense," and well illustrated, it is a most graphic warning.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- The Young Republicans of the State, acting through the governing board of the Association of New York State Young Republican Clubs, demanded today the resignation of Henry P. Fletcher as Republican National Chairman.

FEW observing persons will deny that since the World War the Roman Catholic Church, in spite of such recent reverses as those in Spain and Mexico, has perceptibly expanded its influence and emphasized its authority.

Intercollegiate rowing during 1934 enjoyed one of the most active seasons of modern years and one that saw all of the fixtures restored in this country, with big crowds attending and full entry lists.

While the amended New York City sales tax law, signed by Mayor La Guardia last Friday, broadens the application of the tax and puts teeth into some of its enforcement provisions, it also calls for the setting up of costly additional administrative machinery.

Soviet Russia's recent stand against payment of high interest charges on goods she orders abroad will not affect the purchase of merchandise in this country, semi-official reports indicated here last week. Russia is reported willing to pay 2 per cent more than the normal interest rates in buying goods here, under a debt settlement program she is ready to submit to Washington.

Thirty-seven editors of daily college newspapers pledged themselves to protest vigorously whenever they saw academic freedom endangered and condemned Senator Huey Long for his "unwarranted censorship and suppression of news in the Louisiana State University paper" at the final meeting yesterday of the convention of the Intercollegiate Daily Newspaper Association.
IN the new automobiles for 1935 there is a pronounced trend toward placement of engines further forward in the chassis. The engineers term it redistribution of weight.

THE new Stutz models include two customs lines (single and dual valve) and two "Challenger" lines (single and dual valve). The dual valve models are equipped with downdraft carburetion, combination air cleaner and carburetor silencer, hydrothermic control of intake gas temperature and a combination oil cooler and heater.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 15. -- The heavy demand for labor-saving appliances seems to be already over. Firms are getting rid of the more complicated machinery, having discovered that a calculating machine, for instance, needs an expert operator, otherwise the entire system is thrown out of gear.

The American Olympic Committee approved plans of all its Winter sports committees for final tryouts, team personnel and finances at a meeting at the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Because of the earlier date of the Winter games, these five groups have much more advanced arrangements than any committee for the Summer Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- A reopening by a District of Columbia grand jury of its investigation into charges by a House Mliitary Affairs subcommittee of corrupt practices among some high War Department officials appeared certain today.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- The British Government will begin the new year in an optimistic frame of mind concerning the Continental outlook and the part Britain hopes to play in European international politics.

A SUMPTUOUSLY prepared "Catalogue of Chinese Pottery and Porcelain in the David Collection," by R.L. Hobson, C.B., illustrated with 125 plates in color (others in black and white) and printed in types especially designed by Eric Gill, is announced by the Stourton Press, Dacre Street, Westminster, England.

OF Gladstone in his eloquent moods, Disraeli remarked that he was intoxicated with the exuberance of his verbosity. It is with such vast and vivacious verbiage that Mr. Garvin overwhelms the simpler memory of one who was known adequately to his generation by the monosyllable "Jo."

The practice of port equalization, which has been attacked and defended by ship lines and port groups for several years, is criticized as a drain on the income of intercoastal ship lines and the cause of diverting rather than developing traffic in a statement filed by the Calmar Steamship Corporation with the Shipping Board.

The belief that "women are pretty poor instruments for political action and quite inadequate receptacles for political wisdom" is "a delusion, pure and simple," Dr. Raymond Moley writes in the January issue of the Barnard College Alumnae Monthly, to be published New Year's Day.
Coast Guard planes and cutters searched off the Atlantic coast late yesterday for a fishing vessel carrying ten men out of Sheepshead Bay and bound for Jacksonville, Fla.

In an argument about the Chinese Eastern Railway in Manchukuo, a Russian peddler shot dead a Greek peddler, wounded a bystander and was shot down himself by a policeman outside a crowded West Twenty-third Street ferry slip yesterday afternoon.

It is a generally accepted fact that no matter how pressing the affairs may be with any given group of persons as they scurry in and out of office buildings, department stores and up and down subway stairs, one and all will always find time to gather about a street battle or any other sideshow if the show is interesting enough.

Professional football, in 1984, enjoyed a season that was, beyond any doubt, the finest in its history. Larger crowds, increased interest and a better and more thrilling brand of play sent the pro type of the gridiron game rocketing to a definite niche in the general sports picture.

In a recent letter to THE TIMES J.R. Payson asks a very pertinent question about General McClellan and makes a very reasonable statement, although it is susceptible of discussion. The statement that McClellan never lost a big battle is, of course, a matter of definition.

BY whatever means it is accomplished, the marooning of a group of strangers appears to exert a tireless fascination on novelists everywhere. They delight to invent situations (which thrust ill-assorted folk into one another's exclusive company -- and in fiction at least such encounters are never unproductive of drama.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29. -- Argentina today signed a trade treaty with Spain by which the two countries grant reciprocal customs advantages and other trade facilities.

IT is gratifying to note that the delightful and valuable little "Enjoy Your Museum" series of booklets continues and, apparently, thrives. A previous notice, some months ago, listed a few of these booklets that had already come from the press.
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 29. -- Paterson, surfeited with silk strikes, is beginning to find that being regarded as a centre for labor troubles is harmful in a material way.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Efforts are being made by United States officials in Germany to obtain the release of Miss Elsa Sittell at Waldmohr, Germany.

ONE hopeful sign of a happy New Year comes in forecasts from all parts of the country of more jobs for 1935's graduates than have greeted their brothers and sisters who finished school in the luckless interim since 1929.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 29 (AP). -- Eight persons accused of conspiracy to obstruct justice in the Union Station slayings of five men June 17, 1933, will go to trial in Federal court Monday, Judge Merrill E. Otis said today in overruling six defense demurrers.

Machinery manufacturers catering to the knitted outerwear industry should see sharp advances in their sales in the next few months, Harold R. Lhowe, executive director of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, yesterday predicted, despite the fact that unusual activity in the machinery market recently might be the logical forerunner of a lull.

THE Bituminous Coal Code, child of operator wrangling and suspicion during the first NRA Summer, is back in Washington again, this time being hotly defended by the industry itself against possible extinction. A month ago the National Coal Association became the first management group to ask for code continuation after NRA's two official years shall expire, on June 16 next.

ALBANY, Dec. 29. -- A persistent search was being made tonight by State troopers, forest and game wardens and many volunteers for the four fliers forced down in a snow and sleet storm last night somewhere in the Adirondacks. The men and their American Airline transport plane were somewhere in the mountains, buried in the deep snow that is still falling over a wide area.
