WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- An exhaustive Senatorial investigation of religious persecution in Mexico was demanded in a vigorously worded resolution introduced today by Senator Borah and referred to the Foreign Relations Committee, which is expected to act about Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Under the urgency of providing new relief funds before the present balances are exhausted, the Senate Appropriations Committee pushed forward today in considering the $4,880,000,000 lump-sum program in the hope of having it before the Senate for action early next week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- While government officials express confidence that the administration will be upheld by the Supreme Court's ruling in the gold clause case, conversations between Attorney General Cummings and Secretary Morgenthau are continuing and all angles of the situation are being discussed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Following are the texts of the President's statement on the Automobile Code and his executive order:

No longer need conservative members of the National Arts Club blush when drinking cocktails in their grill, for last night the bar was shorn of its portrait of a lady unaware of the zero weather and a picture of Queen Victoria substituted.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Organized labor came out today in support of Secretary Ickes in his fight to remove from the Triborough Bridge Authority Robert W. Moses, New York Park Commissioner.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 31 (AP). -- The big four of professional tennis -- Bill Tilden, Ellsworth Vines, George Loft and Lester Stoefen -- have decided that the United States will not even reach the challenge round in this year's Davis Cup play.

Shortly before 6 o'clock last night, Mrs. Zena Scala, 20 years old, of 1,711 Eighty-sixth Street, Brooklyn, put on her cloth coat over a housedress and started for the grocery five doors away. A bride of seven months, she was anxious to finish the preparation of dinner for her husband, Joseph, a clerk.

Bank clearings were again higher in the week ended on Wednesday, the total for twenty-two leading cities in the United States being $5,119,085,000, against $4,833,564,000 in the corresponding week of 1934, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- On top of the failure of Strauss Co., one of the biggest British grain firms, yesterday a succession of unrelated shocks cast a cloud of gloom and nervousness over financial London today.

The economic security plan adopted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association at its recent convention will be presented today to the Ways and Means Committee of the House in Washington. The program, regarded as one of the most comprehensive ever devised by a business group, will be offered by a delegation headed by Samuel W. Reyburn, president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation and chairman of the merchants' commitee on unemployment reserves.

A Wall Street corner improved with a twelve-story loft building was put up for sale at auction in the Vesey Street Exchange yesterday. The property, known as 78-80 Wall Street and 154-58 Pearl Street, the northeast corner, was acquired by the Guaranty Trust Company, as plaintiff, on a bid of $218,000.

As part of their convention here this week, the National Association of Merchant Tailors of America, the Merchant Tailor Designers Association and the New York Custom Cutters Club held a dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, which was attended by about 800 persons.

Bernard M. Baruch has come out against the "flat embargo" on the exportation of arms and munitions. He says that "the export of munitions should be controlled through some board which understands international conditions."

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 31 (AP). -The War Department today attributed some of the Mexican rebel movements to followers of General Antonio Villareal, defeated Presidential candidate in the last election, and to "fanatics."

MEXICO, D.F., Jan. 31. -- Rebel groups are active in nine Mexican States, General Manuel Avila Camacho, Under Secretary of War and Marine, reported today to the judges who are trying Andres Pedrero and twenty alleged accomplices on charges of high treason.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- President Roosevelt will soon ask for general legislation centralizing supervision of air, water and highway transportation, he advised Congress today in a special message transmitting a report of the Federal Aviation Commission.

THERE was a general attack along the boxing front recently, but no advance has been noted. Babe Risko attacked Vince Dundee and thought he had gained some ground, but a counter-attack by General John J. Phelan, with Private Brown in support, drove Risko back on his baggage train in great confusion. The wide swinger from Syracuse was lucky that he wasn't captured.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -Twenty years after they first won the national amateur racquets doubles championship, Clarence C. Pell of New York and Stanley Grafton Mortimer of Tuxedo Park started in quest of their tenth title today at the Racquet Club.
In the face of growing protests from all parts of the city, Sanitation Commissioner Thomas W. Hammond insisted yesterday that the job of cleaning the streets of snow was going ahead rapidly.
PARIS, Jan. 31 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Dividends declared in January made a slightly smaller total than a year ago. Payments ordered by 764 corporations totaled $210,792,837, against $212,883,853 for 801 companies in 1934 and $178,839,359 for 739 companies in January, 1933.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Fourteen months of negotiations for settlement of the debts to the United States by Soviet Russia and the claims of American citizens against her were abruptly terminated today when Alexander A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet Ambassador, informed Secretary Hull that an offer made last Fall for adjustment, involving extension of credits through the Export-Import Bank with which to facilitate trade with Russia, was unacceptable.

Although companies representing one-sixth of the railway mileage in this country are insolvent, almost no progress has been made in reorganizing roads which have been forced into bankruptcy or receivership. The desirability of such reorganization has long been recognized.

A year ago, when the State Conservation Council was organized at a meeting in Schenectady, Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne appeared before the gathering of sportsmen and outlined a comprehensive plan for the improvement of public fishing.

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- There are two important factors pressing for tangible results from the conversations that begin in Downing Street tomorrow between the leading British statesmen and those of France who arrived in London this evening.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in January was the slowest for a month since last October. Sales, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 19,409,752 shares, compared with 23,587,502 in December and 54,567,209 in January, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Belief that the government will raise hundreds of millions of dollars through the Treasury's new "baby bonds" was expressed today by Secretary Morgenthau. Legislation authorizing issues of the bonds, to be sold on a discount basis, has been approved by Congress and is now before the President.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Tony Canzoneri of New York, former world's lightweight champion, temporarily dispelled the title aspirations of Leo Rodak, in a bristling ten-round battle before 14,000 spectators in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

Passengers lost their lives in the wreck of the Ward liner Mohawk because the davits of her lifeboats were frozen and the crew was unorganized and unable to handle the situation, according to Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Smith, passengers, of 589 East Twenty-second Street, Brooklyn.

Wall Street found little of interest in yesterday's subdued markets Speculators were satisfied to remain on the sidelines and brokers spoke very guardedly of the immediate future, except to indicate that they will be greatly disappointed if there is not some pick-up in business after the United States Supreme Court rules on the goldclause suits.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31. -Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Williams entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa, where Mrs. Robert McAdoo of New York arrived today. Guests included:

While railroad officials in New York refrained yesterday from commenting officially on the third legislative report of Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator, their previous statements made it clear that they were in agreement with many of his views.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Charging that selfish interests were "out to get him," Secretary Ickes, who has been severely criticized by some members of Congress, charged today that "common cause against me personally and against this department, is being made by certain power interests, hot oil profiteers, crooked lobbyists, equally crooked contractors and certain types of politicians who think more of a few petty jobs than the success of the Recovery program."

GENEVA, Jan. 31. -- After an allday debate in secret the International Labor Office's governing body decided tonight that the permanent members to be dropped from it to make way for the United States and Soviet Russia would be Belgium and Canada.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Jan 31. -Edward J. Reilly of Brooklyn, chief counsel for Bruno Richard Hauptmann, produced two more alibi witnesses today who said that Hauptmann was in Christian Fredericksen's restaurant in the Bronx on the night of March 1, 1932, about the time Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. was kidnapped from his home at Hopewell.

The $4,800,000,000 appropriation passed by the House last week for Federal work relief was attacked here last night by Henry P. Fletcher, Republican national chairman in a speech denouncing the New Deal once more as a failure.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 31. -- The 1933 act providing for reorganization of banks in New Jersey, under which more than twenty banks are now operating, was held unconstitutional in a decision today by Circuit Court Judge William A. Smith. If upheld by the Court of Errors and Appeals, the decision will upset plans for the rehabilitation of the twenty banks.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- President Roosevelt's message to Congress today on aviation and other transport was as follows:

Despite police disapproval, a parade of 1,000 taxicab drivers down Fifth Avenue from Fifty-fourth Street to City Hall this afternoon was threatened last night by the officials of the Taxicab Drivers Union of Greater New York, 142 West Fifty-fourth Street.
MUNICH, Jan. 31. -- The return of Julius Streicher, publisher of the Stuermer, to Nuremberg has brought a sudden collapse of his Munich anti-Semitic campaign.

Detrimental effects of the city sales tax upon retail trade here in tha month just closed were overshadowed by a combination of other adverse factors, particularly the severe weather conditions and to a smaller degree by the uncertainty created by the forthcoming United States Supreme Court decision on the gold clause, local retail executives declared yesterday.

The executive committee of the newly formed Women's Symphony Orchestra of New York announced at a business meeting yesterday afternoon in the Ritz Tower Hotel, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, that Mayor and Mrs. La Guardia and Mrs. James Roosevelt are among the sponsors of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- A Reconstruction Finance Corporation with considerably broadened powers came into legal existence today when President Roosevelt, in the presence of Chairman Jones, signed a measure extending for two years the life of the corporation, which otherwise would have expired at midnight tonight.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 31. -Senator Huey P. Long had his enemies guessing today about what his next move would be to crush the incipient rebellion against his dictatorship. That he would crush it as he has crushed others in the past only the zealots among his foes would question openly.

A message of congratulation from President Roosevelt on the 125th anniversary of the founding of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, and speeches by Bishop William T. Manning and George W. Wickersham, stressing the need for Christian leadership in a time of world turmoil, marked the commemorative dinner attended by 350 parishioners last night in the Hotel Pierre.

The following table gives the amount o dealings in the stock fromwhich the averages are computed, as well as the total dealings in therails and industrials, and the combined trading in both classes of issuesnd the number of the latter appearing in the daily and weekly transactions:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 31. -Hearing of the suit brought by a group of preferred stockholders of the Alabama Power Company to test the constitutionality of the TVA Act was recessed today as the plaintiffs rested.

Huey Long, who recently took time out of his Senatorial duties to dabble in song writing, has just begun a new book, "A Satire on Manners," it was revealed yesterday by Mrs. Long and their daughter, Miss Rose Long, in their suite at the New Yorker.
A group of serious men in greatcoats set up a microphone mounted on a tripod yesterday at Fifty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue at the height of the afternoon shopping rush.

ROBERT NATHAN'S "Road of Ages" (Knopf, $2.50), which is the Book of the Month Club February choice, is as whimsically rueful, as deftly written, as poised and as delicate a thing, as any of the many excellent Nathan novels of the past. But the undertones and the overtones, this time, are more serious, more somber, than is the case with the previous Nathan stories.

MANCHESTER, Ky., Jan. 31 (AP). -- Kentucky National Guardsmen moved speedily and secretly tonight in carrying out an order to "clean up" Clay County, whose bloody history led a Federal investigator to call it "the worst criminal stronghold in the United States."

Preliminary reports of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation covering the results of operations in the quarter ended on Dec. 31 and in the full year 1934 showed small net earnings for both periods after all deductions. A statement by the company made it apparent that business now was of sufficient volume to insure a more substantial balance for stockholders, provided there was no serious setback before the end of the first quarter of 1935.

At 5 o'clock this morning, if plans have worked out, two strangely contrasting conveyances left the car barns of the New York Harlem Railway Company at Madison Avenue and 135th Street. One was an ancient street car, which after a long life of unstinted service, was about to drop dead on its tracks.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31. -- Uruguayan Government forces suffered a defeat at the hands of revolutionists in a five-hour battle at San Ramon, fifty miles northeast of Montevideo, yesterday, according to reports reaching here today. The rebels shot down a government plane during the battle, killing its pilot.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- Otto Marloh, who as a lieutenant in command of government troops during the revolutionary battles of 1919 ordered the summary execution without trial of twenty-nine Berlin Spartacists or Communists, was rehabilitated today fifteen years after the event by the verdict of a military court.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -- The Rev. Dr. J. Gresham Machen, president of the Independent Board for Presbyterian Foreign Missions and Professor of New Testament in Westminster Theological Seminary, denounced tonight the "closeddoor" trial to be held as a result of his refusal to disband his independent Presbyterian Mission Board.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -Judge George A. Welsh in the Federal District Court today gave independent motion picture operators in this area an injunction against nine of the large movie producing and distributing companies of the country, restraining them from enforcing a contract clause which prohibits small exhibitors from showing "double-feature" programs.
Mayor La Guardia expressed elation last night over the action of the PWA in allotting $3,780,000 to the Treasury Department for construction of a Federal power plant in New York City.

J. P. Morgan Co. and the National City Bank as fiscal agents for Argentine Government external 6 per cent bonds due on Feb. 1, 1961, have notified holders that $242,555 is available in the sinking fund for the purchase of bonds tendered and accepted at prices below par.

Yesterday's statement of thetwelve Reserve Banks showed totalgold holdings for the system as awhole and the ratio of reserve tobe at the highest point of the yearto date. The ratio of reserve atthe New York bank also reached anew high figure for the year.

The crew and passengers of the Munson liner Pan America were marooned for several hours yesterday after the liner went aground in low tide not far from her pier at Montague Street, Brooklyn. Coming up the bay from Quarantine, the Pan America, in command of Captain Thomas Simmons, backed up suddenly to avoid collision with a lightship passing across her bow.

The "brazen idiosyncrasies" of the new poetry, which attempts to substitute suggestion through word arrangement and sound for communication through word meanings, were ridiculed last night by Desmond McCarthy, British critic, at the twenty-fifth anniversary dinner of the Poetry Society of America.

It was disclosed yesterday that Borough President Samuel Levy had not authorized the placing of apple-vending machines in public buildings in Manhattan, as officials of the Finance Department have asserted, but had merely notified Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick last October there was "no custodial objection" to the machines.

Edward Albert Ridley, eccentric East Side real estate dealer who was found murdered in his subcellar office at 63 Allen Street on May 10, 1933, left a net estate of $2,861,232, according to the transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

An advance of more than $500,000,000 in member-bank reserves which took place in the last month has lifted such reserves to nearly double the total in 1929, says the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in its monthly review for February.

Last May the Divisional Code Authority declared an emergency and established floor costs for the retail solid fuel industry. You published my deprecation of such action in a letter which evoked sympathetic response. I am saddened by the thought that my pessimism with regard to the effect of such a drastic measure seems to have been justified by what must now be considered a complete failure of the plan to prevent destructive price-cutting.

The foreign exchanges were quiet again yesterday because of the aggressive intervention on Monday of the Treasury's stabilization fund. Foreign currencies advanced moderately, but the rise was equal only to a decline of 0.16 cent in the dollar's gold value, expressed in terms of the French franc, from 101.20 cents on Wednesday to 101.04 cents.

The promotion of the city's new plan for public works aggregating about $300,000,000 calls for the closest cooperation with President Roosevelt's administration and a readiness to meet conditions imposed from Washington, Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday.

Secretary HULL has the respect of all who admire political consistency. He has long been a low-tariff man and has emphasized the necessity of increasing our foreign commerce in every possible and honorable way. But for more than a year he has been caught in a sort of Laocoon coil.

Exports and imports from and into the United States by classified groups of merchandise during 1934, given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with 1933 and 1932. Exports as given in the subjoined tables cover only domestic exports, not foreign goods re-exported.

Germany in 1934 made more thoroughgoing official efforts to keep down her imports and control her trade balance than in any previous year in her history. She began in September her "new policy" which gave the Government absolute control of the volume of imports by setting up twenty-five control boards and requiring importers to have exchange certificates from the Government for everything they brought in.

TORONTO, Jan. 31. -- The New York Rangers tonight downed the vaunted Maple Leafs, 3 -- 2, for their second victory in three days over the leaders of the National Hockey League. The Rangers' 7-5 triumph over Toronto in New York Tuesday night gave them the confidence that produced tonight's hard-earned victory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Without a dissenting vote, the tenth Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense went on record today in favor of the finger-printing of all arriving aliens, the amendment of the Immigration Law to provide for the exclusion for two years of all persons seeking remunerative employment in the United States, and more drastic enforcement of the restrictive provisions of the present law.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 31. -- The Banco do Brasil shipped today $194,456 to New York and 39,800 to London for loan service. The coffee market here is paralyzed and panicky, type seven dropping one milreis an arroba when the National Coffee Department withdrew from the market.

Prosaic critics of the story of the ravens that brought food to the prophet ELIJAH when in exile by the brook Cherith have tried to eliminate the "marvelous element." They call attention to the fact that the consonants in the word which meant ravens might with other sets of vowel-points signify "Arabs" or "merchants" or "inhabitants of Oreb."

The weights for the Metropolitan Handicap, first of the major Spring tests in this district for older horses, were announced yesterday by the Westchester Racing Association, which received them from J. B. Campbell, recently appointed racing secretary and handicapper for the New York tracks.

With money rates in January unchanged from those of the previous month, another month was added to the record period of continuity in fixed quotations. Call loan rates have not been changed since Dec. 7, 1933, and time loan rates since March 6, 1934.

An increase of 47 per cent in the volume of workmen's compensation insurance premiums written last year by the State Insurance Fund was reported yesterday by Charles G. Smith, manager, in a summary of operations for the year.

One of Mayor LA GUARDIA'S first acts was to appoint PAUL WINDELS as Corporation Counsel. His first annual report is good reading to those who hunger for good government. The Corporation Counsel presides over one of the largest law offices in the world, employing 160 lawyers and handling every year some 75,000-odd "litigative matters," many of them of the highest importance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The countries of the world, including the United States, were described today by Secretary Hull and other high administration authorities appearing before the Senate Agricultural Committee as slowly but surely strangling to death their international trade with the devices of their own tariff duties and other extreme nationalistic restrictions.

Snug and warm in our homes, with Old Man Winter knocking at our doors, how many of us, I wonder, give a thought to the city sparrows and pigeons? During a recent storm a friend of mine reports that he observed a pigeon in Central Park walking in the snow to the base of a tree with a peanut in its beak, which the bird gave to a hungry squirrel.
Two leading teams yesterday entered the semi-final round of the second annual mixed doubles indoor tennis tournament at the Island Tennis Club in Long Island City.
PORTSMOUTH, England, Jan. 31. -- C. R. Fairey intends challenging for the America's Cup in 1936 with a Nicholson-designed boat. He already has begun making arrangements.

John Barrymore, dressed in tight gray lounging flannels and a bluish flannel jacket which had served him all the way from Calcutta, arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Rex after a voyage to India to see the birthplace of his father, the late Maurice Barrymore, at Fort Agra.
ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- The maximum salary of J. P. Morgan and other leaders in finance will be only $5,000 a year as far as this State is concerned if Governor Lehman's tax program is enacted.
An industrial building project in North Bergen featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

Applicants for 1935 registration plates yesterday filled the office of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles at 155 Worth Street. It was the last day of validity of the 1934 licenses. Beginning today, all New York motor vehicles must carry the new plates when operated on the public highways.
LONDON, Jan. 31. -- Regular television broadcasting is expected to become an almost immediate reality here following the report of the government's television committee headed by Lord Selsdon today.

A joint recital of music for 'cello and organ was given in the Town Hall yesterday afternoon by Livio Boni and Pietro Yon, the former accompanied at the piano by Arpad Sandor. Mr. Boni disclosed a dignified style and a tone of purity and warmth in music by Martini, Lozo, Popper, and others, and with the able collaboration of Mr. Sandor presented sonatas by Handel and Brahms.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody said today she would start practice in the Spring for the comeback the whole tennis world has been awaiting.

Upset victories by Marvin Kantrowitz of Clinton and Stanley Kaufman of Evander yesterday at the 369th Infantry Armory established these players as finalists in the ninth annual De Witt Clinton interscholastic tennis tournament.

Robert E. Healy, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, predicted last night that, in connection with the registration statements that are to be filed by corporations, the commission would soon make public additional rules to meet specific objections raised by business men.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt tonight were hosts at the third annual State reception on the White House social program, entertaining in honor of Congress members.

Senator William Gibbs McAdoo of California said yesterday on his return from a three months' trip around the world that he was glad that Japan had denounced the Washington treaty because it would give the United States license to develop her navy.

Advance reports on cruise bookings for February indicate that a new high record for the last five years will be established, according to the monthly report of the American Express Company, published yesterday. Business in January was ahead of that a year ago, the report showed.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- The Ardanse sensation is a collection of bouffant evening frocks employing sixty yards of diaphanous material, used over streamlined sheathes that reveal the slim, supple figure. These appear in gossamer lace, fine as a hairnet, hence its name -- hairlace.

Surrogate James A. Foley in a formal decision confirmed yesterday the maintenance order signed on Jan. 18, permitting George W. Wickersham and Thomas B. Gilchrist, legal guardians of the property of Laura Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt, daughter of Reginald C. Vanderbilt, to spend $4,000 monthly for her support, maintenance and education, and the support of her mother, Laura Morgan Vanderbilt, and her maternal grandmother, Mrs. Laura K. Morgan.

PARIS, Jan. 31. -- The Bourse was favorably disposed today. After opening steady the market improved decisively in the last part of the session, closing prices showing small gains over yesterday. The better atmosphere was asscribed partly to the ease with which month-end liquidation was carried out.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31. -- Wood F. Axton, well-known Western horseman, won both divisions of the featured Regret Purse when his homebred fillies, Lillian Uhl and Paradisical, scored today at Hialeah Park. Both tests were at seven furlongs, and the Axton colorbearers carried 108 pounds each, but Paradisical finished in 1:24 4-5, a full second faster than her stablemate.

Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan refused yesterday to grant an injunction sought by a group of theatre ticket brokers to restrain the Legitimate Theatre Code Authority from enforcing the ticket provisions of its code. The court held that the plaintiff brokers, who are members of the Theatre Ticket Brokers Association, had "failed to recognize what the code of fair competition really is."

LONDON, Jan. 31. -- Uncertainty in the commodity markets continued today to have a restraining effect on the stock markets here. British funds were buoyant on good demand, following their recent steady fall. Foreign bonds were inactive.

Uncertainty whether the United States Supreme Court will uphold the government in the "gold cases," issues created by the revaluation of the dollar, caused severe unsettlement in foreign exchange in January and a new influx of gold here. Imports amounted to $130,987,700, the largest for a month since March, 1934, comparing with $85,346,100 received in December.

The Detroit Edison Company reports for 1934 net income of $5,448,331 after all deductions, equal to $4.28 a share earned on 1,272,260 shares of capital stock, comparing with $6,146,369, or $4.83 a share, in 1933.

A plea for the abolition of the city sales tax "at the earliest possible moment" was made last night by Bernard S. Deutsch, President of the Board of Aldermen, in a broadcast over WMCA, the municipal radio station.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was somewhat more active yesterday than on the day before, but the markets there as well as those elsewhere were monotonously alike in their general characteristics. Price movements were extremely narrow in stocks, bonds and agricultural staples, except in a few instances where there was some covering for speculative account in anticipation of a possible decision on Monday by the United States Supreme Court in the gold-clause suits.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 31. -- A list of eighty-five lawyers who have passed examinations entitling them to State certificates as counsellorsat-law was made public here today by the New Jersey Board of Bar Examiners. Only lawyers with counselors' certificates are permitted to practice in the Supreme Court and Court of Errors.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Prices for hogs showed little change here today, although the demand was not aggressive. Receipts were again small, and choice grades sold up to $7.90 a hundred pounds, equaling yesterday's best figure. The day's average of $7.70 was also unchanged.

Approximately 40 per cent of the shareholding reports of 1,300 officers and principal stockholders of listed companies filed with the New York Stock Exchange are obviously inaccurate and many are seriously misleading, it was officially learned at the Exchange yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday the formation of four new member firms, effective today, and the dissolution of four partnerships.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- Prices on the Boerse fell today and many recent gains were wiped out. The movement started with a 3-point loss in Orenstein Koppel, which failed to make an expected dividend announcement. Heavy industrials regained many of their losses before the close, Vereinigtestahl gaining 1/4 point.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 31. -An erratic streak on his tee shots resulted in the defeat of the defending titleholder, Tommy Goodwin of the Winged Foot Club of Mamaroneck, N.Y., in the quarter-finals of the eighth annual National Championship of Golf Club champions today.

John O'Brien, 17 years old, of 36 Laurel Street, West Hartford, Conn., was the subject of three medical diagnoses between 3:30 A.M. and 9 A.M. yesterday before he was taken in an ambulance to Morrisania Hospital.
GLENDALE, Calif., Jan. 31 (AP). -- A sensational 66, four strokes under par, gave Charles Guest, Los Angeles pro, the lead in Oakmont's $6,500 open golf tournament after the first round today.

So badly outdistanced at the start that it had to wage an uphill fight practically all of the way, the Duquesne quintet came on with a rush in the closing minutes of its battle with St. John's at the De Gray gymnasium in Brooklyn last night to win, 34 to 30.
Quiet conditions prevailed in all sections of the money market, resulting in a firm array of quotations which showed no variation.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- What action the law will take in the case of Anthony Vater, whose slap caused the death of his 3 1/2-month-old daughter, will be determined Wednesday by the grand jury of Passaic County. Because of the unusual circumstances surrounding the death the Paterson police and Prosecutor Arthur Dunn will have the jury decide whether Vater should be freed or charged with murder or manslaughter.

The thirtieth anniversary of the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, known as "the radio pastor," as pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, will be celebrated next week. All these years the church has been on the same location, and for long it has had the largest membership of any church in the presbytery of New York.

With a capacity crowd of 16,000 assured as far back as last Tuesday, the Millrose A.A. will stage its twenty-eighth annual track and field carnival at Madison Square Garden tonight. The ticket demand has been of such unprecedented proportions that there will be no gate sale of any description today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Hogs were in fairly good demand here today with the heavy kinds steady to 10 cents a hundredweight higher than yesterday and light weights, which had been under pressure, advanced 15 to 25 cents. The top price was lifted 10 cents to $8 and the day's average was up 5 cents at $7.75.

More than 500 teachers at a mass meeting held last night under the auspices of the Teachers Union petitioned Governor Lehman and the State Legislature to repeal the Ives Teachers Oath Law. The meeting was held in the auditorium of the Central School of Business and Arts at 214 East Forty-second Street.

Although yesterday's temperature did not rise higher than within four degrees of the average of thirty for the date, the minimum of five was eight degrees higher than the low mark for Feb. 1, recorded in 1920. The forecast for today is fair and warmer.

Gulf Stream fishing at Miami, which had been spotty and undependable for several weeks, picked up briskly over the past week-end, according to word received from metropolitan anglers visiting the Florida resort.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 1. -- A proposal by the Chemical National Bank of New York to inject the question of values into the Alabama Power Company TVA suit was rejected by Judge W.I. Grubb in Federal District Court today.

Foreign exchanges cheapened slightly in terms of the dollar yesterday in another period of uneventful trading. The pound sterling was unchanged from Thursday at $4.87 1/8, but the gold-bloc currencies dipped.

BATON ROUGE, La., Feb. 1. -- Senator Huey Long swept like a whirlwind into the capital of his "realm" today and sought to confound his enemies with ridicule, demonstrations of armed strength and sworn testimony that Standard Oil Company employes and anti-Long politicians were fomenting armed rebellion against his rule.

Declaring that it had not approved in full any of the several pending Congressional measures to revise the Federal Pure Food and Drug Laws, as they affect advertising, the executive committee of the Association of National Advertisers yesterday called for public hearings on these bills.

Miss Anne Page of Philadelphia will see her name inscribed on the Junior League invitation tournament challenge trophy for the third time as the result of her squash racquets victory yesterday over Mrs. Ary J. Lamme of Apawamis. In a tense final-round battle that went to five games and took well over an hour to play.

Under a spreading chestnut tree the village smithy stands no more. Country boys and girls must play and picnic somewhere else than beneath its sheltering branches. If they go nutting, it must be for some alien or differing species. Painters have been deprived of a majestic feature of the rural landscape; woodworkers have had to look elsewhere for the material out of which to fashion their posts and ties, crates and coffins.

No final agreement between the city and the B.M.T. on transit unification has yet been reached, although the negotiators on both sides are so close to a settlement that one may be announced within the next few days.

Thomas E. Dewey, former Federal Attorney, appearing yesterday in Federal court as counsel for the Eurydice Gold Mining Company, attacked the practice of the Securities and Exchange Commission of pressing actions against business concerns through its own attorneys.

Contracts to twenty-eight players, including George Herman Ruth, and to two coaches were tossed down the mail chute in the office building occupied by the New York Yankees yesterday as Business Manager Ed Barrow settled back in his chair and expressed confidence that all would come out well.

"A Room in Red and White," which Dwight Deere Wiman and George Kondolf had expected to present on Broadway this Spring, has been postponed until September. Casting difficulties, and the already advanced state of the season, prompted their decision.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Feb. 1. -- Two women, prominent in Suffolk County Democratic circles, picketed the postoffice here today carrying banners in protest of the recent temporary appointment of Andrew J. Melton as postmaster. The picketers contended the appointment by President Roosevelt would mean widespread dissension in the Democratic ranks this Fall.

Comment upon the various doings in cabarets and other nocturnal resorts is necessarily brief this morning. Maybe it's because the mid-season recess is on. Whatever the reason, the biggest event which looms upon the horizon at present will not take place before two weeks hence -- Friday evening, Feb. 15, to be exact.

Commodity futures markets were irregular yesterday, again reflecting uncertainty over the gold-clause decisions expected on Monday. The volume of trading was light and price changes were small. In the cash markets raw sugar, butter and eggs advanced, and all the grains except flour declined, as did lard, lead, tin, silk and cotton.

John M. Trendley of East St. Louis, Ill., the defense handwriting expert, who was testifying when court adjourned Thursday, resumed the witness stand yesterday morning for further direct examination by Mr. Reilly.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 2. -- Akira Ariyoshi's report on the Nanking Chino-Japanese conversations reached the Foreign Office today. Meager and seemingly incomplete accounts in the press represent the conversations as confined to two aspects of the situation, namely, Japanese pressure on North China's borders and the Chinese boycott of Japanese goods and other anti-Japanese movements.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- Because the immediate supply of defense witnesses for Bruno Richard Hauptmann was exhausted today and also because the defense will need time to serve subpoenas on thirty to thirty-six more witnesses, Supreme Court Justice Thomas W. Trenchard granted a request by Edward J. Reilly, Hauptmann's chief counsel, for a week-end recess in the murder trial.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now, offered by dealers:

Alfred A. Cook, who proposed the plan of reorganization on behalf of the Paramount Publix Corporation, will submit early next week to Federal Judge Coxe an order to show cause why certain modifications in the plan should not be accepted and approved by the court.

David North, 32 years old, a dealer in old gold, was shot and killed under mysterious circumstances early last night as he entered the vestibule of the five-story apartment house in which he lived at 2,146 Grand Avenue, near East 181st Street, the Bronx.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 1. -- The defeat of Celeste Durand of the Timber Point Club, Great River, L.I., winner of the qualifying medal, furnished another upset in the semi-finals of the eighth annual national championship of golf club champions today.

An attack of grip which was severe enough to lead examining physicians to declare there was danger of it developing into pneumonia yesterday overtook Art Lasky, Minneapolis heavyweight, and necessitated a postponement of his fifteen-round bout against James J. Braddock, which was scheduled for last night in Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The substantial reduction in stock market transactions in 1934, as compared with the year before, was indicated today by an Internal Revenue Bureau statement showing that the tax on capital stock transfers amounted to $20,768,427, as compared with $40,248,971 for 1933.

A resolution endorsing the bill proposed by State Senator William T. Byrne providing for the mandatory inclusion of women on jury rolls, was adopted yesterday by the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at its ninety-sixth convention at the Hotel Astor.

Having just washed his hands of European disputes, Senator BORAH plunges them into one nearer home. Opposition to the World Court was largely based on the plea that we must have nothing to do with the internal quarrels of foreigners. But now comes the Borah resolution calling for a Senate inquiry into the religious strife going on in Mexico.

With traders continuing to twiddle their thumbs, the speculative markets were wholly lacking in energy yesterday. Wall Street looked on without apparent interest, but continued the futile debate over what the United States Supreme Court may do with respect to the gold-clause matter.

The State Recovery Act was held invalid by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn yesterday. Holding that the State Legislature virtually had surrendered its sovereign legislative powers to Federal administrative authorities, the court ruled this action conflicted with constitutional provisions designed to prevent that evil.

The first of the monthly index numbers, published yesterday by Dun's Review, shows advance of 2 1/8 per cent in the average of commodity prices during January, the sharpest rise of any month since September, 1933. The current index number is the highest since that of May 1, 1930.

After a week of brooding because another woman had been dismissed when she got a job, Mrs. Edna Wueller, 39 years old, a dress designer, committed suicide yesterday by jumping from the roof of the five-story apartment building in which she lived at 587 Fort Washington Avenue, according to the police.

Chase Mellen Jr., New York County chairman, and Charles E. Buchner of the Seventh Bronx Assembly District were elected yesterday members of the executive committee of the Republican State Committee from the First Judicial District at a meeting of the State committee members of the district at New York County headquarters, 50 East Forty-second Street.

The Port of New York Authority will market new bonds this month up to a maximum of $35,300,000 as the first step in consolidating its bonded debt, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank C. Ferguson, chairman of the Board of Commissioners.

Wallace Havelock Robb, Canadian naturalist-poet, gave a translation into the language of man, in poetry and in prose, of some of the things he has been "told by the birds" before an audience at the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences last night.
The value of the dollar on the local foreign exchange market, based on quotations for the French franc on the days indicated, compares as follows. Quotations are in cents:

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- The grain markets fluctuated erratically again today, with the volume of business limited. The trade continued to act cautiously pending the Supreme Court decision on the gold-clause case.
TRENTON, Feb. 1. -- Governor Harold G. Hoffman said today that his sales and income tax program would be laid before the Legislature as originally planned.

I wish to back up William C. Adams's claim that there are fur-bearing trout in the mountain lakes of our great West. Ten years ago I saw an actual photograph on a picture postcard of such a fish and the fur very closely resembled that of the marmot which inhabits the region.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1. -- Sound Advice, 3-year-old son of Vice Counsellor and Wise Mother, won his second straight victory today by capturing the $1,000 Azusa handicap at Santa Anita Park.

GLENDALE, Calif., Feb. 1. -- The country's leading golfers paced by the Carnoustie veteran, Macdonald Smith, took the Oakmont Club course apart today as they paraded through the second round of the Oakmon $6,500 open golf tournament.
The job of clearing the snow from the city streets moved more rapidly yesterday due to an increase in the army of snow removal workers to 45,000 men and to the slight upward turn in the temperature.

Giulio Gatti-Casazza received in his office at the Metropolitan Opera House, Seventh Avenue corner, yesterday the advance guard of well-wishers bringing congratulations on the general manager's birthday. He will celebrate that anniversary tomorrow by spending a quiet Sunday in his apartments at the Savoy-Plaza.

Roman Catholics will be urged on Feb. 10 to exclude from their homes all reading matter "that ventilates obscene news and licentious scandals" by Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral and Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York.

TOKYO, Feb. 1. -- Interpellation in the House of Representatives today on the financial effects of continuance of the present heavy armament expenditures elicited statements from the War and Navy Ministers that Tokyo financial circles consider reassuring.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- With diplomatic representatives from the competing nations looking on, Sir Samuel Hoare, president of the British Lawn Tennis Association, today drew from the gleaming silver Davis Cup the pairings for the 1935 international tennis team competition which sends the United States against China in its first match.

Seven educational, religious and charitable institutions receive bequests totaling $22,750 in the will of Harry de Berkeley Parsons, consulting engineer and yachting authority, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday. Mr. Parsons died on Jan. 26, leaving an estate formally valued at "more than $20,000."

MOSCOW, Feb. 1. -- Radical changes in the Soviet Constitution in the direction of a more democratic form of government -- although by no means toward democracy in the Western sense, which is still anathema here -- were decided upon today by the Central Committee of the Communist party.

The American Library Association has put forth the statement that five hundred large public library systems "might" provide more adequate service for all the people of the United States than is now made available by numerous independent libraries "which" reach only 60 per cent of the "population."

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- Citing the issues involved in the case of Bruno Richard Hauptmann, the Law Revision Commission in its annual report to the Legislature today announced it would submit measures looking toward the adoption by New York State of a uniform extradition law.

HONGKONG, Saturday, Feb. 2. -- A British airplane roared over the coastal steamer Tungchow at noon yesterday while her passengers, prisoners of pirates, cheered wildly, and the outlaws, who had seized the ship soon after she sailed from Shanghai Tuesday, fled for shore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum at the close of the week ended Jan. 26 totaled 320,570,000 barrels, according to data compiled by the Bureau of Mines, Department of the Interior. In comparison with data for the previous week, this total represents a net decrease of 551,000 barrels, comprising decreases of 522,000 and 29,000 barrels, respectively, in stocks of domestic and foreign crude oil.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- A bill to give New York City instead of the Board of Education control over the salaries of custodians of public schools was introduced today by Senator Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d. Republican of New York.
Attorney General David T. Wilentz took over the witness for cross-examination. He got the witness to testify that he had not written his information to James M. Fawcett, Hauptmann's original lawyer.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 1. -- A high Japanese official declared today that no specific claims and demands had been advanced during the interviews this week when the Japanese Minister, Akira Ariyoshi, and the military attache, Lieut. Gen. Yoshimichi Suzuki, visited Nanking and conferred with the leaders of the national government.

CLEAR the track for the Wanamaker mile. Years ago it was the Cubs against the Giants in baseball. A bit later it was Jerry Travers against Francis Ouimet on the links, and still later it was Francis Ouimet against Chick Evans on other courses. There was Big Bill Tilden against Little Bill Johnston on the courts. There was Bob Jones against Hagen for a while, and finally Bob Jones against the field, with no takers.

The Fidelity Fund, Inc., reported yesterday that on Dec. 31 its assets totaled $4,166,006, against $3,741,698 at the end of 1933. Shares owned by investors increased from 74,152 to 93,053. Cash income from interest and dividends was $113,984, against $73,893. Cash income in the fourth quarter was $42,009, against $24,202 in the same period of 1933.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 1. -- Directors of the Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation were directed to pay a dividend of $7 to holders of 7 per cent prior preference stock in the $35,000,000 company by Judge Ernest H. Wells in Hustings Court, Part II, today.

Imre von Csernyak, former captain in the Hungarian Army and at one-time commander of the Hungarian revolutionary army, appeared at Ellis Island yesterday for a preliminary hearing on charges made by the Immigration Bureau that he entered the United States illegally ten years ago.

Alexander Wilbourne Weddell, United States Ambassador to Argentina, will sail today for Buenos Aires, via Europe, on the Italian liner Rex, accompanied by Mrs. Weddell. Others sailing in the ship for Mediterranean ports are:

The brilliant concert given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall was a triumph for the band and the leader. The peerless quality of the strings was published with the very first chords of the Haydn G major symphony.

The National Steeplechase and Hunt Association has granted twenty-four sanctions for race meetings during 1935, according to an announcement yesterday by Frank J. Bryan, following the annual session of the organization.
A cable was dispatched to the Cambridge University Rugby Club yesterday inviting the English team to visit the United States this year and make a tour similar to the one of last Spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1. -- The defending champions, J.W. Brooks and Huntington Sheldon, and the game's most renowned pair, Clarence C. Pell and Stanley G. Mortimer, went down to defeat today in the semi-finals of the national amateur racquets doubles tournament at the Racquet Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The administration's banking program has been virtually completed and when it goes to Congress will be in a single bill containing three sections. These will cover amendments to the Federal Deposit Insurance Law, clarification of some sections of the Banking Act of 1933, sponsored by the Federal Reserve Board and the Controller of the Currency, and recommendations for giving added powers to the Federal Reserve Board.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- For nearly eight hours today the leading French and British Ministers have discussed the general European situation in a formal conference in Downing Street, and the discussion will be continued there tomorrow.

The New York Stock Exchange notified presidents of listed corporations yesterday that the Exchange would not waive its requirement that they submit financial statements to stockholders fifteen days in advance of annual meetings. The companies sought additional time so that they could make their fiscal reports correspond with Form 10, recently promulgated by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HONGKONG, Saturday, Feb. 2. -- The coastal steamship Tungchow, carrying seventy American and British school children in charge of five British teachers, arrived here today after having been freed from the grip of Chinese pirates by British naval planes.

Edward McLoughlin, special deputy superintendent of insurance in charge of rehabilitation of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, announced yesterday a payment of $240,000 in interest to 3,500 holders of certificates of the $27,889,158 Series F-1 mortgage issue.
A digest of The Associated Press transcript of yesterday's testimony at the Hauptmann trial follows:

Martin O'Connell, 30 years old, a former prizefighter, died at 12:30 P.M. yesterday in Metropolitan Hospital on Welfare Island, thirteen hours after he had been shot in the stomach by one of two youthful hold-up men at Michael Goldstein's gasoline station, 1,909 First Avenue.

Two new finalists will meet on the courts of the University Club today to decide the Class A championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association. They are Robert Grant 3d, former Harvard star, representing the Harvard Club, and R.A. Goodwin, Yale Club player.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1. -- Anastas Mikoyan, named today to the Com munist Political Bureau, is a nephew of Joseph Stalin, the general secretary of the Communist party. M. Mikoyan is a son of M. Stalin's sister.

Refusing to obey the order of four hold-up men, two armed with pistols, to "get in the back of the store or get shot," Adolf Tutzauer, 35 years old, proprietor of a raw fur wholesale business on the ground floor at 128 West Twenty-seventh Street, was shot in the chest about 5:15 P.M. yesterday.

GENEVA, Feb. 1. -- An agreement has been reached between the workers' group in the International Labor Office's governing body and the American Federation of Labor under which the United States will get one of the eight seats in this group.
ATLANTIC CITY, Feb. 1. -- Women bathers may wear the new lace swimming garb next Summer on the beach at Atlantic City and at the neighboring resort of Ventnor.

American radio men yesterday applauded England's move to introduce television to the public, but were quick to explain that by no means does the British step signify this country is to be left behind in the television race.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Declaring Congress has unlimited power in prescribing regulations for spending money on public works projects, District Supreme Court Justice F. Dickinson Lefts today dismissed a suit brought by A. Ames Co., a New Jersey manufacturing concern, which asserted that it had been discriminated against in public works projects.

In a setting of yellow, green and white Spring flowers, the last for this season of the Junior Assemblies was held last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. Jonquils, budlea and bridal wreath entwined the grand stairway which leads to the foyer of the ballroom, where the committee received against a background of mimosa and forsythia.
Today the eyes of the world will centre on that perennial visitor, the lowly groundhog. Those of the groundhog faith will scan the skies anxiously.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Following on the collapse of the Russian debt negotiations, preparations were furthered today for dissolution of the first Export-Import Bank, established to facilitate trade with Russia through the granting of credits to American exporters. Its dissolution has been suggested by Secretary Hull, who regards it as no longer necessary.

BELGRADE, Feb. 1. -- Several hundred university students started a hunger strike today in sympathy with their comrades interned in the Visegrad concentration camp in Bosnia. When police tried to storm the building a fight ensued in which one student is believed to have been killed and seventeen wounded.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1. -- Two definite statements regarding the Uruguayan revolt came from Montevideo today. One was a categorical statement by President Gabriel Terra that "the revolution is all over and finished," and the other was a decree issued by him calling up the army and police reserves to double the strength of the present armed forces "during the continuance of the abnormal situation."
Three children were rescued at a Brooklyn fire yesterday when their grandmother dropped them, one by one, from a second-story window into the arms of waiting neighbors.

A proposal to increase commission rates about 16 2-3 per cent in order to restore gross income of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange to the 1924-25 level was forwarded yesterday to several firms by Hallam Boyd of Frazier, Jelke Co., Ruloff E. Cutten of E.F. Hutton Co. and Robert W. Atkins of Abbott, Proctor Paine.

Elaborate police precautions frustrated yesterday an attempt of the Taxicab Drivers Union of Greater New York, an independent labor organization, to parade in their cabs down Fifth Avenue and thence to City Hall to lay their grievances before Mayor La Guardia.
The Triborough Bridge will be opened to traffic on July 1, 1936, the Triborough Bridge Authority said yesterday when it sent three progress charts to PWA Administrator Harold L. Ickes in Washington.

MADRID, Feb. 1. -- Spain is slowly but surely liquidating the October revolution. An infantry sergeant who deserted to the rebels and a Socialist Asturian miner, who himself commanded a firing squad at the execution of eight Civil Guards, were shot at dawn today in Oviedo.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- President Roosevelt announced that he would send to Congress within two weeks a message on ship subsidies' and legislation for safety at sea.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP). -- Black Stockings, A.J. Halliwell's consistent veteran campaigner, ran another one of his good races today to take the one and one-eighth mile top event at the Fair Grounds.

"Monetary experts" in the Senate who have complained recently of an apparent let-up in the Government's purchases of silver can find no cause for dissatisfaction in the most recent figures of the Department of Commerce. They show imports of this metal during the week ended Jan. 18 valued at more than $5,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP). -- The national Retail Code Authority reported to the NRA today that the employment provisions of the Retail Code should be continued temporarily, but that consideration should be given the problem of the small store.

Ivan Poderjay, 35 years old, former captain in the Jugoslav Army, whose second wife, Mrs. Agnes C. Tufverson Poderjay, disappeared mysteriously from this city on Dec. 20, 1933, pleaded guilty in General Sessions yesterday to a bigamy indictment based on that marriage.

Standard Brands, Inc., and subsidiary companies reported yesterday for the twelve months ended on Dec. 31 a net income of $13,878,021, applicable to the parent company after charges and reserves. This was equivalent, after preferred dividend payments, to $1.06 a share on 12,645,380 shares of common stock outstanding.

Federal conciliators intervened yesterday to avert the strike of 75,000 teamsters and longshoremen threatened next week if Supreme Court Justice Burt J. Humphrey issues an injunction restraining union workers from interfering with non-union truckmen in the movement of freight to and from steamship piers.

The city of Boston, Mass., announced yesterday that it will open bids on a new issue of S4,000,000 of temporary loan notes on Monday at noon. The notes will be dated Feb. 6 and will mature on Nov. 4. Interest will be payable at maturity.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 1. -- The Dartmouth College athletic council reported a deficit of $46,274 for the college year ending June, 1934, in a statement released today.

The social problems of the mountain folk in the region of the Tennessee Valley must be met on a vast scale and through the cooperation of Federal, State and private agencies, according to leaders who attended the annual meeting of the International Save the Children Fund of America, held yesterday in the Town Hall Club.

Homer J. Standee, a prominent figure in New York transit history, does not quite see eye to eye with the Mayor about buses and street cars. Mr. LA GUARDIA says that with the advent of the Madison Avenue buses the transportation problem is almost solved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- In anticipation of Congressional action to expand its capital, the Home Owners Loan Corporation today directed its workers to begin exam ination of 350,000 applications for loans.

In reference to your editorial "Stable Currencies," may I express my general agreement with Sir Henry Strakosch's six preconditions preparatory to stable exchange on any restored gold standard -- namely: (1) Internal equilibrium of price level; (2) determination of foreign exchange to correspond; (3) adequate gold reserves; (4) freer trade; (5) war-debt cancellation; (6) lessened variability in value of gold.

Capturing all eight first places and five seconds as well, Yale's unbeaten varsity swimming team scored its 133d consecutive victory last night when it defeated City College, 57 -- 14, at the C.C.N.Y. pool in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association dual meet.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1. -- The running of the Miami Beach Handicap Stakes at Hialeah Park tomorrow afternoon will be featured by an attendance of many notable box groups and will be preceded by a number of luncheon parties in the clubhouse.
The decade culminating in 1929, it is now conceded on all hands, was insane. One of the forms taken by this insanity was our importation of useless gold instead of goods.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 1. -- Members of the China Inland Mission, including many parents who passed anxious hours awaiting word of the steamship Tungchow's fate, gathered informally tonight to celebrate with prayers and expressions of thanksgiving.

Mrs. Reginald Cuyler Elphinstone gave a reception yesterday afternoon at her home, 59 East Seventy-seventh Street, for her brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Clarke. Among the others present were:

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 1 (AP). -- Attorney General Charles J. Margiotti announced tonight that a State employe and the head of a Marietta laboratory will be charged with conspiracy in the distribution by the State of more than 1,100 doses of diphtheria anti-toxin which was impotent because of age.
Yale's "iron men," the 1934 football team, came in for a great deal of attention last night as they visited the city for a dinner at the Yale Club.

"Inquiries," as the French term our "symposiums," are made continually by French newspapers. Liberte is conducting one on this momentous theme: "Why and how did you select a pseudonym?" The well-known poet who disguises himself as "Tristan Dereme" is more interesting as an illustration of POPE'S dictum, that of all mankind poets are most absurd, than in his interpretative distich about his own literary alias.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- President Roosevelt revealed today that he would discuss the ship-subsidy question in a message to Congress in about two weeks. He also indicated that a comprehensive shipping program, including safety-at-sea legislation drafted under the direction of Secretary Roper, will be forwarded to Capitol Hill at the same time.

A decision regarded as of great importance in the manufacture and interstate distribution of wines by non-resident wineries and wholesalers was handed down yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Edward S. Dore. Justice Dore held that a contract to purchase wine from a California winery was valid and enforcible here, even though the winery had no license from the New York State ABC Board.

The DeWitt Clinton High School basketball team, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, conquered Stuyvesant High, 29 to 21, yesterday in a non-league contest in the Clinton gymnasium for its fourth victory in six games this season.

For several consecutive years the Weyhe Gallery, 794 Lexington Avenue (between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets) has presented, in the course of the season, a selection of "Fifty Modern Prints" by American artists. It is an event toward which the art world has learned to look forward, certain of finding here work that evidences progressive thought and fresh points of view.

While the grand jury was investigating yesterday the alleged theft of $25,000 in bonds by Maurice Gallaher, 44 years old, a former investment dealer at 1 Wall Street, who disappeared last November, the District Attorney's office asked the police to send out an alarm for his arrest.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 1. -- There was a strike on the coffee market today, commission merchants refusing to show samples and the Coffee Exchange finding no buyers for futures. Late this afternoon, however, coffee brokers started curb selling of futures and the market closed firm up to 300 reis an arroba [about 2.5 cents for 32-38 pounds].

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, At Sea, Feb. 1. -- The Wyatt Earp expects to reach Montevideo tomorrow afternoon on its return from the Antarctic and from there I shall return to New York. The ship will remain at Montevideo awaiting orders.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- Characterizing executives of the leading news-reel companies of the country as "cheap tricksters," Attorney General David T. Wilentz demanded tonight that motion pictures of the trial in progress, "procured by trickery," be withdrawn at once from circulation.

James J. Bambrick, president of Building Service Employes Union, Local 32 B, predicted last night at a mass meeting of union members at Rockland Palace, Eighth Avenue and ,155th Street, that a strike of major proportions would start at the end of next week against building owners if all of them did not comply with the arbitration board's decision.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Significant changes in the President's social security plan, designed to take the onus of charity off unemployment insurance and also to save the government several hundred millions a year, were reported today to have been mapped by administration officials.
The Fordham basketball team went a long way toward atoning for several setbacks as it scored a surprising triumph last night over the powerful Syracuse University quintet, 27 to 24.

Divers who have been at work in the Ward liner Mohawk, seventy feet below the surface, off the New Jersey shore, returned to New York yesterday to report that the hulk contains none of the bodies of the passengers and seamen still missing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- PWA legal experts pushed forward today with the drafting of model legislation for States, to enable them to clear the way of legal barriers to take full advantage of the administration's new $4,880,000,000 work relief program.

The hearing on the petition of the National Hand Embroidery Association in the Port Authority Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, for release from the home-work clause of the industry's code ended yesterday in a clash in which one of the spokesmen for the manufacturers characterized members of the Code Authority as "racketeers."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- There was considerable speculation here today over whether the Securities and Exchange Commission might temporarily suspend trading on the Stock Exchanges under its jurisdiction if the Supreme Court on Monday should hand down a decision adverse to the government in the gold-clause case.
LONDON, Feb. 1. -- An important new theory of the origin of the cosmic rays was propounded today by Professor Edward A. Milne, Oxford physicist, writing in the scientific weekly, Nature.

Two young artists of more than every-day equipment, Adele Marcus, pianist, and Sonia Essin, contralto, shared a recital program in the Town Hall last night. Both had been heard here before. Miss Marcus began the evening with the Busoni transcription of the Bach chaconne, which she played with much spirit and no mean command of technical resource.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- The breakdown of the Russo-American debt negotiations has aroused considerable attention in Germany because the Reich is negotiating a 200,000,000-mark trade agreement with the Soviet [the mark was quoted at 39.99 cents yesterday.]

Irving Thalberg will supervise Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's film version of Franz Werfel's book, "The Forty Days of Musa Dagh." The cast has not been chosen yet, but it will list the names of the company's chief players, according to the announcement. . . . Other Metro bulletins: Lucien Hubbard has signed a new long-term contract as producer.

Two men, the first to be arrested in the recent drive by the police on a petty loan shark racket in the financial district, in which minor employes of banks and brokerages were forced by "strong-arm" tactics to pay a yearly interest rate of 1,040 per cent on small loans, were sentenced in Special Sesisons yesterday.

THE TIMES printed a letter from Cordelia B. Makarus defending the trucker of coal from the mines. Your correspondent resents, with some justice, the imputation that all the trucker contributes to the State is a pair of license plates, and also objects, not without reason, to any suggestion that all truckers of coal are bootleggers.

BERLIN, Feb. 1. -- The Boerse was somewhat stronger today, but rather quiet. The market strengthened when the most conservative of the larger banks, and the least under government influence, the Berliner Handelsgesellschaft, raised its dividend rate from 1 to 6 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A resolution calling upon President Roosevelt to dismiss three Federal employes as "contributors to the cause of communism," and to conduct a searching investigation for the purpose of "weeding out" of the government service "hundreds of communists" reported to be on Federal payrolls was adopted today by the Tenth Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 1. -- George Wells Ely, 53 years old, a retired insurance broker, was found wounded fatally by a gun tonight in bed at his home at 19 Nirvana Avenue, Nirvana Gardens, a suburban development of Great Neck.

BOULDER DAM, Nev., Feb. 1 (AP). -- For the first time in its history, which geologists say is some 3,000,000 years, the turbulent Colorado River was halted today and brought under control for the benefit of man.

Playing at top form all the way and yielding only seven games, Marvin Kantrowitz, third seeded entrant, captured the honors yesterday in the final of the ninth annual De Witt Clinton High School interscholastic indoor tennis singles tournament at the 369th Infantry Armory.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1. -- Lee Rosenberg's 3-year-old filly Dowdy Dell triumphed by half a length in the fifth race at Hialeah Park today to gain her second victory of the Florida season and the third of her career. The race was the second division of the Everglades Purse, the first going to Everett McGehee's Headin Home, which scored by a head.

A violent explosion, following a leak in a gas main that had been reported by the police more than six hours earlier to the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, killed a police sergeant and injured ten other persons yesterday in front of the Ludwig Baumann furniture store at Hoyt and Livingston Streets, Brooklyn.

President ROOSEVELT has sent to Congress, with a partial and qualified recommendation, the full report of the Howell commission, appointed by him last year to investigate all phases of aviation with a view to recommending an intelligent and far-sighted Federal policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor, highest authority of organized labor between conventions, went on record tonight as protesting against the procedure adopted by the Roosevelt administration in "imposing" the extension of the Automobile Code on labor.

Spectacular competitions among the packs of hounds in four division marked the tenth annual hound show at the Riding Club yesterday. A gallery of hunting enthusiasts from all parts of the country was in attendance and applauded the splendid control of the various famous packs as they paraded up and down the spacious riding ring to the music of the huntsmen's horns and the guidance of the lashes of the whippers-in.

Most of the important markets remained yesterday in a state of suspended animation. There was further anxious discussion of the possibility of a decision on Monday by the United States Supreme Court in the matter of the abrogation of the gold clause in bond contracts.
LONDON, Feb. 1. -- Engineers of the British Broadcasting Corporation took swift action today to implement the government's authorization of a public television service.

Forty-two communities will be in the market next week with new bonds and notes amounting to $18,186,930. This week's revised total of new bonds up for award is $15,009,173. The weekly average for the year to date is $17,451,627. Most of next week's new issues are in the high-grade classification.

Gano Dunn, president of the J.G. White Engineering Corporation and long active in science, engineering and education, has been elected president of the Board of Trustees of Cooper Union to succeed the late R. Fulton Cutting, it was announced yesterday.

Floyd L. Carlisle, head of the Consolidated Gas System, spent his second day on the stand yesterday before the legislative committee investigating public utilities listening to criticism of the tactics of his company presented in the form of verbal attacks and comparative figures on rates.

The New York Stock Exchange placed on exhibit yesterday about seventy-five additional reports of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed corporations, as required by Section 16 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

Members of the New York Yacht Club displayed keen interest yesterday in the news that C.R. Fairey, British yachtsman, intends challenging for the America's Cup. The first definite knowledge of Mr. Fairey's plans came with the cable from London to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Prince Hubertus Loewenstein, author of "The Tragedy of a Nation: Germany, 1918-1934," recently published by Macmillan, will arrive here on the President Harding today to start a lecture tour. He has just come from the Saar Basin, where he campaigned against Hitler until the eve of the plebiscite.

Entry of the United States into the League of Nations was favored by 32,404 and opposed by 32,320 students in the first returns in a peace poll of 119 American colleges and universities conducted by The Literary Digest in cooperation with the Association of College Editors. Tabulations of the returns from sixty institutions appear in the current issue of The Literary Digest.
Three exhibitions opened with a reception and private view last evening at the Brooklyn Museum. Opening to the public today, they will be on through February.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- The story of the death of Violet Sharpe, 28-year-old English housemaid, who committed suicide June 10, 1932, by drinking poison in the home of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, where she had been employed, was told here tonight for the first time.

Society and the fine arts joined once again to present the annual Beaux-Arts Ball last night in the Grand Ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria. Glowing with the color and romance which marked a bygone era in English history, the event was given under the auspices of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects in beautiful settings typical of regal splendor.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- The stock markets here were generally firm today with increased activity. British funds were higher on investment buying. Foreign bonds were better, Japanese and Brazilian issues rising. Among the industrials Television shares strengthened further on a good report.

Extremely low temperatures again spurred the sale of Winter merchandise in stores in the metropolitan area during the week. Stocks of most seasonal items, particularly women's and men's coats, gloves, protective footwear and undergarments, have been sharply reduced and rush orders were placed with manufacturers to replenish stocks.

Lending institutions continue to find a ready market for apartment houses having good tenant rosters. This was demonstrated yesterday in Brooklyn, where two well-rented multi-family buildings were sold by savings banks.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday the appointment of a committee of eighteen, headed by Dock Commissioner John McKenzie, to coordinate the efforts of various shipping groups and chambers of commerce to develop the commerce of the port and protect commercial interests against the inroads of rival ports.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Details of a shipbuilders' conference in a hotel here in July, 1933, when the 1933 naval construction program is believed to have been considered, were sought in vain today by the Senate munitions committee as it renewed its inquiry into activities of Arthur P. Homer.

Operations on the Cotton Exchange were mainly routine again yesterday with new business held in abeyance pending a decision by the United States Supreme Court in the gold-clause cases. After steadying in sympathy with the course of other markets on Thursday, prices eased slightly and ended at losses of 4 to 5 points.

NANKING, China, Feb. 1 (AP). -- General Chiang Kai-shek, military head of the Chinese Nationalist Government, today denied vigorously current reports that a Chino-Japanese rapprochement had been planned that would make China economically dependent upon Japan.

Motor-bus operation on Madison and Fourth Avenues got off to an auspicious start yesterday, according to spokesmen for the Madison Avenue Coach Company. The reaction of the riding public to the new service, which replaced the old street-car line between Madison Avenue and 135th Street and Broadway and Ann Street, confirmed the company's announcement.

A parcel comprising thirteen buildings in West Thirty-first Street, west of Eighth Avenue, was among the seven Manhattan holdings bought in at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Four Bronx properties also went to mortgagees. The results were as follows:
Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices in New York:

The New York Produce Exchange took the first step yesterday toward discontinuing its securities market by announcing a large number of listed issues in which trading will be suspended on Feb. 8. The Exchange in a statement several weeks ago said it would abolish its securities division entirely on Feb. 28.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A bill authorizing the Home Owners Loan Corporation to issue an additional $1,250,000,000 in bonds, $250,000,000 of the amount to he made available to the 600 Federal savings and loan associations to make funds easily obtainable for the construction of about 40,000 new homes and for home repair jobs has been completed by HOLC attorneys.

Declaring that some one had "blundered dismally" in the medical treatment given to 17-year-old John O'Brien of West Hartford, Conn., by ambulance surgeons last Thursday, Mayor La Guardia started an investigation of the circumstances yesterday.

In an opinion handed down yesterday Judge Grover A. Moscowitz in the United States District Court declared the Prudence Company, Inc., was not a banking institution in fact but a business concern entitled to reorganization under Section 77b of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- The Bourse ended the week badly after several good sessions. Few values escaped the downward trend, and since no signs of resistance manifested themselves during the day, closing prices were the lowest of the session.
